story:
What is the NorthEnd Urban Arts Festival?

The North End Urban Arts Festival is a call for creative uprising in one of Wichita’s most diverse, yet under celebrated neighborhoods. A project of the ICT-Army of Artists, the festival is part of a campaign of cultural interventions that build community identity by cultivating art from the ground up. By elevating the talents and joy within our neighborhoods, the ICT-Army of Artists and the North End Urban Arts Festival invites the community to recognize and collaborate in bringing out the creative potential that exists around us every day.


//We have big dreams and a sincere vision//

The ICT-Army of Artists is a volunteer based effort whose current mural project has hit walls across Wichita and headlines across America. The first and most recognized mural celebrating the rich history of the North End’s immigrant roots went up last summer. 

Since then, a mural bringing out the richness of Kansas history has gone up in Delano, and another, celebrating the empowerment of women through education and experience, is set to go up in the North End. During the festival, participants will work together to create the ICT-Army of Artists’ first mobile mural celebrating LGBTQ rights and the freedom of identity. This mural will travel around the city and state to churches and other sites that support acceptance of identity and the arts.

The funding collected through this campaign will be used exclusively to cover costs associated with the production of the festival. We want to present a high quality festival that attracts young audiences from across the city. 

We are committed to local artists, makers and creators, to elevate their businesses and to contribute to the local economy. It is in that spirit that we seek to broaden the horizons of community expression, and setting the precedent a high quality festival and cultural interventions to come.

     


The Impact

The North End Urban Arts Festival will introduce new mediums into the ICT Army of Artists’ arsenal of creativity. With international cuisine, live music, and extreme sports taking to the stage throughout the festival, The North End Urban Arts Festival is broadening the horizons of community expression, and is setting the precedent for cultural interventions to come. In keeping with the ICT-Army of Artists’ tradition of participatory art, the festival will feature hands-on workshops and exhibitions from some of the cities brightest artists and collectives. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    You want to help but can't do it financially?? We have opportunities for you! Visit our website www.NorthEndUrbanArtsFest.com for volunteer opportunities, to become a vendor, display your art or become engaged in the many ICT ARMY of Artists cultural interventions! 

    • Tell your friends about the festival and how to get involved!
    • Don't forget to click the "SHARE" button and spread the love!

story:
NOTE: The 24 hours of drawing has already happened. If you're donating after 10/5, please only pick download perks. All drawing took place on 10/5, and no more drawings will be created at this time. 

Art Heals

I draw for 24 hours straight. You donate to Healthright International in Ukraine.

You get to tell me what to draw. The art starts on October 5th.

The fundraising starts today!

Here's the story...

My character, Milo the Cloud, is usually the way I connect to the world. I draw and write Milo stories and comics in order to remind people that kindness works, that compassion is something to revere and strive for in our every human (or meteorological) interaction. Milo is always giving, and caring, and loyal. He's what I hope to be. Drawing Milo, and drawing in general, is a healing act for me. It helps me heal some of the sickness and despair I see in the world around me. If one person a day has their spirits lifted because of a Milo comic, or finds inspiration from Milo Decides To Be, then I consider that a pretty great day.


We Can All Heal Together

The thing about writing and drawing, is that it's pretty solitary work. I can sit down and draw with my daughter, and I can write a comic while my wife is sitting on the couch next to me, but I'm in my head all alone. Sometimes I feel the need to collaborate. I feel the desire to be a part of something greater than I could accomplish on my own. Here's where I'm hoping you'll join me on a little journey. My wife is from Ukraine, and so over the last half year we've watched her homeland torn in two, her people bleeding and dying. And we've talked about how helpless we feel to do anything, or make any kind of impact.


24 hours

On October 5th, I'll be sitting by a window, in the 24 hour Starbucks at Piper's Alley in Chicago, drawing. I'll draw and paint for 24 hours, only stopping to eat a bit of something, and to sneak off to the bathroom for a minute or two. The idea is to draw for donations. You'll donate whatever you can to Healthright International's programs in Ukraine, via this IndieGoGo campaign, and I'll turn your donation into a work of art that you get to keep. We'll have some time-slots set up, so that when you donate 25 bucks, you get a 15 minute sketch, if you donate 100 dollars, you'll get an hour long sketch. It'll be first come-first served, so in order to make it fun for everybody, even after the time-slots are gone, I'll make sure that people who don't get an original will be able to download a hi-resolution digital copy of whatever sketch or drawing you like from your donation level. I'll also have some higher level perks for outrageously huge donations. We'll figure it out together, and maybe you can help me by suggesting perks you'd like to see.


(Quick aside, just so there's no question: IndieGoGo has to say that bit about "All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose." but I've spoken with Healthright International and they assure me that once the campaign is over, they can direct the money to their initiatives in Ukraine. So donate with confidence that your money is going where it needs to go.) -Sean

I feel the desire to be a part of something greater than I could accomplish on my own. Here's where I'm hoping you'll join me on a little journey. My wife is from Ukraine, and so over the last half year we've watched her homeland torn in two, her people bleeding and dying. And we've talked about how helpless we feel to do anything, or make any kind of impact.24 hoursOn October 5th, I'll be sitting by a window, in the 24 hour Starbucks at Piper's Alley in Chicago, drawing. I'll draw and paint for 24 hours, only stopping to eat a bit of something, and to sneak off to the bathroom for a minute or two. The idea is to draw for donations. You'll donate whatever you can to Healthright International's programs in Ukraine, via this IndieGoGo campaign, and I'll turn your donation into a work of art that you get to keep. We'll have some time-slots set up, so that when you donate 25 bucks, you get a 15 minute sketch, if you donate 100 dollars, you'll get an hour long sketch. It'll be first come-first served, so in order to make it fun for everybody, even after the time-slots are gone, I'll make sure that people who don't get an original will be able to download a hi-resolution digital copy of whatever sketch or drawing you like from your donation level. I'll also have some higher level perks for outrageously huge donations. We'll figure it out together, and maybe you can help me by suggesting perks you'd like to see.(Quick aside, just so there's no question: IndieGoGo has to say that bit about "All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose." but I've spoken with Healthright International and they assure me that once the campaign is over, they can direct the money to their initiatives in Ukraine. So donate with confidence that your money is going where it needs to go.) -Sean

story:
Short Summary

This country is the land of opportunity, they say, and at the age of 41, I decided to take the biggest risk of my life. I sold everything  I owned, moved myself and my dog to New York City from California to pursue my career as an artist, full time.

My name is Louise Rachel Kerr and I have been an artist all my life.

My goal while in New York, is to see artists valued and supported as integral parts of a community and help art collectives spring up to connect and brighten the places in which we live. While, I simultaneously complete my masters degree in painting.

My passion and vision in the arts often has meant working in a solitary environment, and expressing a personal and vulnerable piece of myself to be viewed. I want to collaborate with other artists and make work that contributes to communities and help provide education to the future artists of our world. 

I believe being an artist is my calling. I want to do the work that quietly waits inside of me, collaborate with like-minded artists to create large public works on buildings, in parks and in schools. In order to accomplish this I have taken a huge leap of faith and returned to a rigorous studio practice and further technical schooling.

Since my arrival in New York, I have started to create a collaborative of like minded successful fine artists, including painters, poets, graffiti artists, muralists and musicians, to create a large piece of public work that will be completed in the fall of 2015. 

This collaborative effort will enhance and beautify the New York City area and bring attention to art as an important part of our communities as well as help promote the artists. My vision and mission with this project is to have these collaborative groups of artists pop up and spread to every city, create links within communities between art and how it contributes to our lives.

In this place of creative collaboration, true passion often is poured out, creating ripples outward for all to be inspired and for all to enjoy.

About the artist

I grew up in extremely rural Scotland, without electricity or running water, until I attended art college in the city of Glasgow at the age of 16. My love of drawing and painting sprouted at only three years old. 

Throughout my art career, I have faced the adversity of the struggling artist. I work very hard creating works of art but to support such creativeness, I sought jobs and opportunities to make ends meet which often pulled me away from the constant creation of my work.

As the years raced by, it seemed like I relied heavily on chasing what might sell in an effort to just make a living, keep a roof over my head and food on my table. At that moment, I realized my current situation was stifling my pure expression, exploration of new ideas and personal study as an artist. The world and all of its distractions had me working more and more part-time, non art related jobs for basic financial security. It was most difficult trying to develop my art-making on the side because I could not afford nearly enough time or concentration that the creative art process requires. I started to ask why? nearly every artist I know struggles this way.

Art is vital to our lives, it expresses so much and colors the world we live in so vibrantly. Yet Artists are not valued as they once were in the days of old, when the masterpieces we house in museums today were created.

Imagine a world without art.


I am determined to complete my studies; be the best maker of art I can be; create works of art, connect groups of artists to collaborate, and support each other in a way that will have an impact on connecting communities around the world.


What We Need

Against all odds I was accepted into the prestigious New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture. 

It was extremely obvious to me that returning to study as a student was the only way that I can accomplish all that needs to be done. It is not only necessary as a matter of learning different techniques, paths of thought and interacting with like-minded peers, but it will allow me to find my own personal style and discover my true identity as a maker of art.

The school accepted me based on the strength of the work that I produced in their summer program, just one month before classes started. I have almost completed the first 6 months and my work has improved exponentially. I have a gap of time before I can get public assistance and apply for loans. 

I haven't been in school in over 20 years! My records are proving hard to acquire from Scotland since the College I attended no longer exists. As a result, I am required to do pre prequalifier 1 year certificate course that will roll into the 2 year Masters in Fine Arts. I need to raise the funds necessary to pay for the last 6 months of my tuition, art supplies and rent. After completion of this initial year, I will be able to apply for loans to help cover the additional MFA 2 years.

All donaties will be used for this purpose and the creation of the artists collaborative.


Graham Nickson - Dean of the New York Studio School.

Ron Milewicz - Drawing Professor

Critique with Professor Judy Glantzman

Stretching Canvas 

My studio space at the New York school of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture. Current work in progress


    The Impact

    Connecting large groups of artists to create public works that better our communities also enhances and gives great creative expansion to everyone involved.

    It is my belief that a true artist should be given the opportunity to create art purely from their soul. When an individual is able to express that what is their passion and calling, you experience something profound and are reminded that we can achieve anything, inspire others and live out loud -- with purpose.


    For once in all artists lives, they should be able to express and enhance their talents, freely without reservation, not driven by a financial need or what trends demand; but in a collaborative and nurturing environment, that enhances the expansion of both the artist and the work.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Thank you so much for supporting the arts. Every dollar amount is one step closer to reaching the goal to share expand art throughout the world; and you can be a part of it. 

      Other ways to support? You can share my campaign on your social media sites and ask for the support of those I may not know yet. Just share the link below: 

      https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/contribute-to-education-creation-of-public-art/x/8332359
      and say how you know me and ask your friends to donate to art!

       

      Another way you can support this cause? Get on board with my art collaborative by emailing me at louisesart@gmail.com. Help me create something magical….be part of the group of artists committed to creating awareness and public works.

      Rosie Lopeman - collaborative artist.

      Dana Blickensdurfer - collaborative artist.

      Ben Moon - collaborative artist.


      Who is Louise Rachel Kerr?

      Louise Rachel Kerr was born in a very rural part of Scotland and has been painting and drawing from the age of three. 


      Growing up with no electricity until she was twelve, art was truly her passion. Both of her parents had been artists and drawing every day was highly encouraged. She was accepted into Art College in Glasgow at the age of sixteen for architecture and fine art. 

      Moving to New York in 1991, She discovered soft pastel and studied under some of New York’s finest pastel artists, Daniel Greene and Suzanne Young, to name a couple. She was also a member of various art leagues both in Manhattan and Long Island. She started giving live portrait demonstrations in pastel. 

      While living in New York, she was invited to exhibit her work in six Starbucks locations, paving the way for other artists nationwide.

      Due this exposure, private collectors started purchasing her work.

      In 1999 and 2000, she won first prize in pastel for the New York Art League and exhibited in The National Arts Gallery of Manhattan and the Coe Hall Museum on Long Island. 


      In 2005, she moved to California and became a US citizen. she has participated in the local art festivals for which Laguna is famous, has had numerous shows in her own gallery and studio and has been a member of the Laguna Canyon Artist studios since 2007. She is an active participant and donates of work to the Laguna College of Art And Design annually and was featured in American art collector 2013 for the above work titled 'Grey Muskoka day'. 
      She currently maintains a studio in Laguna Beach and is working on a new body of work in Manhattan at the New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture. She is currently studying with Graham Nickson, Judy Glantzman and Ron Milewicz.

      The new work is often large scale, combining oil paint and other wet mediums on paper and canvas. 
      Although primarily figurative, the New York Studio school with its esteemed alumni of artists such as De Kooning,  and Philip Guston, has opened a new abstract nature and exploration.


      Please help me make a difference in the arts.

story:
BRUSH|REED has been invited to perform in Hong Kong by the Hong Kong Wind Ensemble! Help us fund our journey and keep the BRUSH|REED project thriving!

As artists in association with the non-profit Music Performance and Education, Inc., all donations to BRUSH|REED are tax deductible!


Our Story

We are BRUSH|REED

The BRUSH|REED project is a collaboration between painter Linnea Doyle (Los Angeles) and saxophonist Dr. Jennifer Bill (Boston).

The artists join together to explore the parallels between painting and music via live stage performances. Jennifer transforms the printed notes of her musical score into lush soundscapes, Linnea further interprets the music into visual color and form on her fresh canvas.

The music is inspired by the artist and the artist is inspired by the music

The live art that blooms at every BRUSH|REED performance captivates and moves audiences. The paintings that emerge establish a visual memory of the sights, sounds, and emotions of each intimate affair, impressing upon each audience member a feeling of symbiosis between the two disciplines presented to them.

BRUSH|REED engages an audience through color, pitch, representational lines, rhythm, intensity, and expression... A true aural-visual experience.

Origin

BRUSH|REED was conceived in the Summer of 2008 on a warm, humid afternoon in Minneapolis, when the painter and musician—both originally from the area and friends since 1995—were brainstorming a way to fuse their respective arts. BRUSH|REED emerged as an experience designed to cross disciplines, unite their passions, and highlight the close relationship between music and visual arts for audiences around the world.

Linnea & Jennifer set a goal of ten engagements that would ultimately culminate into a traveling exhibit featuring each of the original paintings, audio recordings, and a video presentation of the performances.

To date, BRUSH|REED has conducted six performances and one workshop, totaling seven engagements:

  • February 1, 2009 | Providence College, Providence, RI
  • September 25, 2009 | Boston University, Boston, MA
  • July 5, 2011 | Tanglewood, Lenox, MA
  • July 10-15, 2012 | St. Andrews, Fife, Scotland
  • October 22, 2013 | Buffalo State, Buffalo, NY
  • October 23, 2013 | Mansfield University, Mansfield, PA
Future engagements include this campaign's destination of Hong Kong and, in 2015, potential performances are slated for Sydney, Australia, and the World Saxophone Congress in Strasbourg, France.

Hong Kong 2014

BRUSH|REED has been invited by the Hong Kong Wind Ensemble to perform in Hong Kong on June 1, 2014.  The performance will be held at the Hong Kong City Hall Theatre.

In addition to the BRUSH|REED performance, Dr. Bill will be teaching a masters class, guest conducting, and performing a concerto with the Hong Kong Wind Ensemble on May 25, 2014 at the Hong Kong City Hall Concert Hall.

Why we need your help

Since inception, BRUSH|REED has been a labor of love and entirely self-funded. 

This campaign will support BRUSH|REEED's upcoming two-week journey to Hong Kong, which begins on May 19th, 2014. Donations will fund international travel expenses including airline tickets, baggage fees for instruments and equipment, paint and canvas, saxophone equipment, international work visas, transportation, lodging, and food. If the full goal amount is met and additional funds are raised, BRUSH|REED will also be able to hire a tour manager / photographer / videographer to assist with and document the experience.

Help us as we continue to work toward the BRUSH|REED project goal of ten performances and traveling exhibition. Your support ensures the project continues to thrive!

Spread the word!

Share our campaign to as wide of an audience as you can! Tell your friends, your work buddies, your family, and your Facebook about our project. Any donation helps and is greatly appreciated!


Credits

This Page
Linnea Doyle photo © Travis Anderson

Hong Kong Promotional Video
Produced & Directed by: Linnea Doyle & Dr. Jennifer Bill
Produced & Edited by: Trevis Carletta
Photography:
Linnea Doyle photo © Tim Davis
Various performance photos courtesy of Molly Walker and David Faleris
Hong Kong Skyline (aerial) © Steve Carney (CC BY-SA)
Hong Kong Skyline (harbor view) © Peter Nijinhuis (CC BY-NC-ND)
Hong Kong City Hall Memorial Garden © Kwong Yee Cheng (CC BY-NC-SA)
Music: Allemande from Partita in A minor
Written by J. S. Bach, Performed by Dr. Jennifer Bill

All other content © BRUSH|REED. All rights reserved.

story:
We are a local Denver Rum company and we support our local street & pop art collective. Help us give these artists a chance by getting them in local career changing events.

What We Need & What You Get

We will be matching contributions from our campaign, to sponsor our local artists in events like the Cherry Creek Arts Fest, Denver Arts Festival, Denver Chalk Art, and events like these.

At specific levels of donation, you will get special perks, including our first limited edition CO flag Squeal Rum Logo Sticker. The best part is, if we see you around town with the sticker on your car, we may stop you randomly and give you some SQUEAL merch, pretty sweet!

The Impact

Many of the street, graffiti, tattoo & pop artists have a hard time getting into 'main stream events.' Whether it's financial or just becoming accepted. We want to give these artists a chance. If we can help pay for them to have a spot to showcase their stuff, we can help give them a chance that we couldn't usually give them,

Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on facebook, sign up to be added to our list on our website, and more to keep updated on events, and more chances to get involved; Squeal Rum.com.

story:
Our Story

The Battle of the Canvas ® is a live painting competition that encourages the involvement of emerging and professional visual artists to paint under a theme that will promote social change through artistic images.  In addition to fusing diverse artists with different skill levels together, encouraging the appreciation of visual arts outside of galleries and museums is our goal since this free event will allow the public to connect with and interact with artists as they paint.  We provide a different dimension to the painter-patron relationship by allowing potential patrons to see the full artistic process and watch a blank canvas transform into a work of art.  We highlight multiple forms of creative expression by inviting various diverse bands, musicians, DJs and dancers from the Philadelphia community to perform.   The Battle of the Canvas® is an all inclusive arts event that showcases the power of visual and performing arts while implementing social change.

 


The Impact

The Battle of the Canvas is for YOU! This is an opportunity for artists of all disciplines to come together and showcase their talents, products, artwork, skills, etc. If you are battling...paint like you've never painted before!! If If you're a music performer/DJ..this is an opportunity for you to display why you are an authentic artist and should be taken seriously. Vendors...in order to establish a following, you have to expose yourself. The imprint you make on the Philadelphia community will be lasting...make it count! This is a space for all of that and more. Bringing all different disciplines of artistic expression together, in one place for artists to be seen, network and develop a larger audience is what the Battle of the Canvas is about!


What We Need & What You Get

The Battle of the Canvas is a community focused project that was developed to expose untapped visual and music artists in the Philadelphia community. By participating in this campaign, you will ensure the continued growth of the project and the artists that are supported. We will be raffling off artwork, that will be painted live that day to supporters of our campaign. We are asking for your support towards the development of the project sot that August 27th will stand alone as one of the most unique events to hit Philly yet! We aim to keep this event FREE for our audience and at a low cost for artists to register. Your support is very important as the Battle of the Canvas aims to fully provide all that the participants may need to make this event a success and to continue the production of the event annually.


Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD SPREAD SPREAD the word about the Battle of the Canvas!! "Like" us on Facebook, Tweet about our continued updates, learn about the artists, our sponsors, the musicians and DJs. Make this one of the biggest events to hit Philly this summer!!!

visual and performing arts while implementing social change. 
 


The Impact
The Battle of the Canvas is for YOU! This is an opportunity for artists of all disciplines to come together and showcase their talents, products, artwork, skills, etc. If you are battling...paint like you've never painted before!! If If you're a music performer/DJ..this is an opportunity for you to display why you are an authentic artist and should be taken seriously. Vendors...in order to establish a following, you have to expose yourself. The imprint you make on the Philadelphia community will be lasting...make it count! This is a space for all of that and more. Bringing all different disciplines of artistic expression together, in one place for artists to be seen, network and develop a larger audience is what the Battle of the Canvas is about!


What We Need & What You Get
The Battle of the Canvas is a community focused project that was developed to expose untapped visual and music artists in the Philadelphia community. By participating in this campaign, you will ensure the continued growth of the project and the artists that are supported. We will be raffling off artwork, that will be painted live that day to supporters of our campaign. We are asking for your support towards the development of the project sot that August 27th will stand alone as one of the most unique events to hit Philly yet! We aim to keep this event FREE for our audience and at a low cost for artists to register. Your support is very important as the Battle of the Canvas aims to fully provide all that the participants may need to make this event a success and to continue the production of the event annually. 


Other Ways You Can Help
SPREAD SPREAD SPREAD the word about the Battle of the Canvas!! "Like" us on Facebook, Tweet about our continued updates, learn about the artists, our sponsors, the musicians and DJs. Make this one of the biggest events to hit Philly this summer!!!

story:
UniqTeas are as unique as you.

Have you ever wanted a tea flavor that simply doesn't exist? Now you can create your own unique blend with your name and photo on the packaging!

Uniqteas lets you show the world that you are unique too! We have created a really innovative system for you to create your own unique flavor mix and then we package it in a custom can that features your name and the flavor name you choose.

We have perfected our system and now we want to offer it to the world. We just need your help to begin the creative process!

We need your help

We are asking for your help because we think this is a truely unique idea that the world of tea drinkers is thirsty for.  People are demanding good healthy food and we are offering premium teas customized to their individual tastes and then packaged uniquely for them.

Everyone who Pledges will get their own Uniqtea custom blend, and the knowledge that you are doing something truly unique!

Quotes from other UniqTeas customers:

“I can create exactly the flavor I want and it’s just for me and my friends.”

“What a thrill! I choose my blend and then it’s delivered with my photo and name on the canister!”

“I created a special flavor for my wedding guests. They will enjoy the tea and then keep the canister forever.”

“I love fruit blends but I can never find the right mix. This gives me exactly what I want.”

“My friend Jill created a really tasty blend and then I was able to buy it too.”

"My boyfriend and I got a personalized tea for Christmas this year and it was so great. Tea was quality and packaging was creative! We smile every time we make this tea"

We search for the best teas.


A few months ago we decided to help all the other tea drinkers out there experience blends that they create to fit their own unique tastes.  Using our new innovative tea blending app anyone can create a blend.  Guidance is even provided to help with blend selection in the form of a unique Flavor Profile widget that changes as you adjust the tea blend percentages.

 


Once our customers create their blend, we package it in an air tight canister, and add their personal choice of name, description and photo.


The result is a UniqTeas blend that shows your personal style and taste.

 

We have been selling UniqTeas for the last few months, and the response has been incredible. In fact, we need to add to our production equipment and purchase larger orders from our incredible growers. That’s why we are asking the tea loving community for help. Every pledge is vitally important to us, and together with our thanks, you’ll receive UniqTeas, blended specifically for you.

 

Rewards

Here’s a breakdown of our reward levels:

 

Goals

We are reaching for $15,000 so we can purchase a new faster and more cost effective digital label printer.  Below is a picture of the printer.  If you all help us reach our goal we will pitch in an extra 5 pack sampler to all pledgers.

story:
THANKS FOR LOOKING AT THE DREAMCYCLE!

WHO I AM AND WHY I AM DOING THIS?

Thanks for checking out my project! I am Keith. Forever I have loved art and how it affects people.  The power that art has on an individual can be the best! It's free and its REAL.  When someone feels positive emotion from observing a piece of art it is a gift. This intangable gift is why I love art.  The Dreamcycle is einginereed to deliver feelings relaxation and creativity in whoever is observing it.  I invite all these emotions into anyone who chooses to or happens to be around my art project for Burning Man this year Dreamcycle.  

WHAT THE DREAMCYCLE IS

It's devised from Brion Gibson's Dreammachine, a device which Timothy Leary called "the most sophisticated neuro-phenomenological device ever designed."  Basically it is created to bring the observer into a state where they experience alpha brainwave functioning.  Alpha-waves are associated with a healthy mind and a stress-free life. For those of us with mentally taxing jobs and stressful lives, Dreamcycle can restore order and relaxation. When your brain operates at this level of electical activity you become overwhelmed with feelings of relaxtion, euphoria, and creativity.  The Dreamcycle stimulates this type of brain functioning through creating a series of patterned lights that flicker due to a rotating cylinder.

The difference in the Dreamcycle and the dreammachine is that the Dreamcycle is in the true Burningman spirit. Its is a mutation that is dwelling into the unknown.  The Dreamcycle cylinder is large enough to sit in and recieve the beneficial light pattern from the intense hot dessert sun.   What is unknown with the Dreamcycle is whether or not the sun's heat interacting with our sense of feeling with enhace the dreamcycle's ability to induce alpha brainwave functioning.  This unknown is very exciting.   

WHAT MAGNITUDE OF YOUR CONTRIBUTION IS

Contributors can feel good knowing that they are helping to create a sacred space that can have the ability to enrich anyones reality in a positive way.  They can also feel good about contributing to the arts, creativity and the human spirit!  Contributers of $25 up to $100 will get have the option to get any initials welded onto the Dreamcycle.  Contributers of $100 or more will get any name welded onto the project in large easily viewed letters.  This can be your physical mark on the dreamcycle displaying your contribution and support.  Even if you are not going to the playa this you will beable to come in spirit with the Dreamcycle. 

WHAT THE DREAMCYCLE NEEDS TO COME TO LIGHT!

The Dreamcyle is being created from almost entirely repurposed material which will keep the cost's down.  This includes almost everything from the steel to gears to bicycle parts, and even the nuts and bolts.  I have done everything in my power to keep this project as cheap as possible and am proud to say that through work trade I have gotten it down to be very inexspensive.   However there are a few purchases, which are to ESSENTIAL the Dreamcycle to be used during the night hours when it is dark wich is the intention with the device.  This is necesarry to keep the project SAFE due to it being located in the open playa at Burnigman.

They are...

  • 90 degree gearbox=                                      225$ 
  • 60 tooth sproket=                                          30$   
  • 70 ft el wire=                                               60$
  • Small solar powered lights x 3=                        45$
  • Large solar powered lights x 2=                       120$
  • 4x8 18 gauge steel x2(for the rotating cylinder)    90$

THE IMPACT

The Dreamcycle aligns with the observer's naturally occurring alpha brainwaves.  When this happens the alpha wave becomes dominate in the observer.You could achieve the same "alpha state" after learning and practicing meditation, or by training yourself with bio-feedback machines, however the Dreamcycle offers you a fantastic light show and relatively quick alpha-wave production. People find that in the past dreamachine therapy and other alpha-wave related therapy lead to decreased anxiety, overall calmness, increases IQ scores, increases in brain hemisphere coordination and overall intellectual function.  When complete the Dreamcycle will be a tool and a portal which can help heal the world through individuals feelings of peace!  Contributers can feel good kowing that they are contributing to this cause and doing their part to help keep Blackrock city safe and a place of expirenmentation.

The more money Dreamcycle can make the more illuminated it can be, wich in turn will draw more attention to it, thus enlighenting more people with its meditative effects!  This is a project geared towards enhancing peoples' experience on this planet! 

Remember that this goal is a bare minumin for the potential of this project.

Any additional money that I can raise will be put to exceptional use to bring the dreamcycle into full potential at Burningman.  The more money I can raise the better and more erotic I can illuminate the Dreamcycle.

Please, If you beleive in my project even if you can't contribute tell all your friends, family, co-workers anyone who is interested in the arts!  And also please come find the Dreamcycle at Burningman this year!  I look forward to seeing you!

story:
My name is Monica Chulewicz and ever since I’ve found out I have a progressive mitochondrial disease, I’ve wanted to do something to spread awareness and better yet, raise funds for a cure; and what better way than to use my own artistic abilities?

My most recent work stems from my personal struggle with memory loss when my mitochondria become faulty (more than usual). As well as the loss of memory, I hope to express through my work a sense of realization of mortality; a thought that every mito patient is worrisome of. 

With this project, “Creative Mitochondria”, I will be making various prints of my digital collages, in the form of both screenprints and transfer prints. The funds gained for this project will directly go to supplies (i.e. paper, screenprinting emulsion, laserprinter copies, acetone). After creating as many prints as I have enough supplies for, I will sell my prints (through my Esty shop) with all proceeds going toward mitochondrial disease research.*

With selling my artwork, not only will I be raising funds but I hope to raise an awareness of these diseases as well. If you cannot donate money for my project, please donate your time in spreading awareness. Thank you.

*All proceeds will be going to United Mitochondrial Disease Foundation (UMDF.org)

story:
About me

Hi! I am Jane Labowitch, AKA Princess Etch A Sketch. I am a 22-year old etch a sketch artist. I started playing with an etch a sketch when I was about 4. My grandma wouldn't let me watch TV all that much when I came over to visit, so I played with my etch a sketch instead. I guess the main difference between me and every other kid is that I never stopped playing with it! My staircases slowly evolved into boxy images and soon I figured out that when you turn both knobs at once, you can make diagonal lines and curves. From that point on, my skills with an etch a sketch grew with my skills as an artist. Since I started taking more seriously to the knobs, I have been blessed with some awesome opportunities. Most recently, I've been invited to show my work at Who's Next, a fashion trade show in Paris.

This brings me to why I am funding $1000. As I am sure you can imagine, going to Paris isn't cheap! I am prepared to cover my own flight. But I'd like to reach out to you to help me fund my stay in Paris. 

When I was first contacted about this opportunity, I almost passed it up when I learned I'd have to cover my own expenses. But my friends and family got me thinking that maybe it's worth the financial plunge. I'm not expecting to make this money back, even though I'll have a chance to sell my work while there. But opportunity only knocks once. So I might as well answer the door! There will always be more money, but who knows if I'll ever get invited to show my work in Paris again? Even if it's a total bust, I'd rather be able to tell people about that time I went on a crazy excursion to Paris, than to look back on my life and think "what if?". I'd feel a fool to deny myself the possibilities that could await me in Paris. 

This will be my first time traveling outside of North America. I'm nervous, but excited! Contributing to this project will allow me to share my art with an entirely new audience. Let's show France what an etch a sketch can really do!

What I need

I am looking for $1000 to fund my stay in Paris. I expect to be there for ~6-7 days. The money would cover my lodging, as well as food. This will also cover the cost of some of the promotional materials I will be shipping ahead of time, such as business cards and prints.

I'm offering all sorts of incentives for those who would like to contribute. I'm offering original etch a sketch art and prints, as well as some original art and prints of my illustrative work. Check them out!!!

If I don't reach my goal, I will pinch my pennies where I can. I'll find the cheapest baguettes in town! I'll get cozy with strangers in a hostel! I'll try to find plane tickets where I would stay in Paris for less time to save on lodging. But the best tickets I've found allow for about a week of staying in Paris. So I'll do my best to fund like no tomorrow!

More About Who's Next

Here's a link to the trade show: http://tradeshows.whosnext.com/

and the facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/whosnextpap

The theme for this year is toy, which is why I was contacted. They'd like to feature my etch a sketch art at a booth during the expo. I will also be able to do an etch a sketch art piece live that would be completed during my time at the expo. I'd have the opportunity to etch people's portraits live as well. 

The etch-a-sketch was invented in France, and is known as the Telecran. So it's very appropriate that they would like to show my work! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word! The more people who know, the more likely my stay in Paris will be funded. Remember to use Indiegogo share tools! This will better help me promote on this website.

Also, if anyone happens to know someone who lives in Paris, I'd love to get connected! It would be really great to have someone I could show me the ropes while in Paris. I don't know anyone there!

Where to see my etch a sketch art

I've got my art all over the internet. Here's a list of websites where I show my work:

http://princessetchasketch.com/

https://www.facebook.com/princess.etchasketch

http://pikajane.deviantart.com/

http://princessetchasketch.tumblr.com/

Here are some select images of my most popular work:

 

  

Thank you so much!

Let's get this funded by Christmas! :)

story:
Tattoo Me
My name is Mike Watt, I'm an artist based in Sydney, Australia. 

I've put together a collaborative book called Tattoo Me. I draw a unique character for an artist and they tattoo it, and pretty much do whatever they want to it. 

             

The book is 144 pages with over 130 collaborations.
I've been working on this book on the side for almost 3 years. I'm very happy and proud that so many amazing artists contributed. I would love the chance to get this project out there for people to see.
The profits will fund the exhibition/launch of the book and a website.
Below are some spreads from the book.

Bec Kilpatrick, Ben Brown

Carl Morgan, Chris Nixon

Georgia Hill, Gina Kiel

Kentaro Yoshida, Keo Match

Phibs, Pigeon Boy

Sam Brunell, Sammy Bats

Sticker Ap, dye cut sticker. 5.8cm x 15.25 cm

                        

A2 screen printed poster by Arcade Screen Printing on black card.

Artists featured include...

6SETA, ADAM TOHT/ATOMOL, ADRIAN REPETI, ALEXANDRA LEDERMAN, AMY BEAN, ANDREW MILLIST, ANDRI MONDONG, ANDROS, APE 7, BAFCAT, BEC KILPATRICK, BEN BROWN, BEN OWENS, BEN MARRIOTT, BEN MITCHELL, BILL HOPE, BILLMUND, BIRDHAT, BORJA BONAFUENTE GONZALO, BUNKWAA, BUTTONS, CAM SCALE, CAM WALL, CARLOS BOBI, CARL MORGAN, CHRIS NIXON, CHEHEHE, CHRIS WAHL, CRABLO, CRISIS, CULT DE SAC, DAVID CRAGG, DAVE FOSTER, DEAMZIE, DEANIST, DIGABLE GOODS, DOGFIGHT, EDDY-LOU, ELEVEN, ELSA ISABELLA, FERNANDA PORTO, FIELDEY, GABRIELLE FILTZ, GARETH LLOYD, GEORGE ROSE, GEORGINA ANTON, GEORGIA HILL, GINA KIEL, GLENNO SMITH, GRIZZLE, GRIM FINGA, GWEN WATT, HOUL, HULES, IRENE FELEO, IRESH, ISA FLORY, JAKPOT, JAMES BRISCOE, JACK DOUGLAS, JAK M.C.S, JASON PAULOS, JAYA, JESSE BROCKIS, JIMMY SK, JOE42, JO LEY, JOAO PERES, JON FOYE, JOSH 2000, KALIS, KARL TAGLE, KENTARO YOSHIDA, KEO MATCH, KRISPE, LACHLAN BRUCE, LADY J ADAMS, LEE McCONNELL, LOSOP, LOUIE JOYCE, LUCY IZZARD, LUKE OKAY, LUSCH, MARTIN E WILLS, MATTHEW BOURNE, MATT DAMPNEY, MATT JACKSON, MELLO, MICHAEL LANGENEGGER, MIKE MAKATRON, MITCH WALDER, M-LON, MULGA, MR. story_txt:
Tattoo MeMy name is Mike Watt, I'm an artist based in Sydney, Australia. 
I've put together a collaborative book called Tattoo Me. I draw a unique character for an artist and they tattoo it, and pretty much do whatever they want to it. 

             
The book is 144 pages with over 130 collaborations.I've been working on this book on the side for almost 3 years. I'm very happy and proud that so many amazing artists contributed. I would love the chance to get this project out there for people to see.The profits will fund the exhibition/launch of the book and a website.Below are some spreads from the book.Bec Kilpatrick, Ben BrownCarl Morgan, Chris NixonGeorgia Hill, Gina Kiel
Kentaro Yoshida, Keo Match
Phibs, Pigeon Boy
Sam Brunell, Sammy BatsSticker Ap, dye cut sticker. 5.8cm x 15.25 cm                        A2 screen printed poster by Arcade Screen Printing on black card.Artists featured include...6SETA, ADAM TOHT/ATOMOL, ADRIAN REPETI, ALEXANDRA LEDERMAN, AMY BEAN, ANDREW MILLIST, ANDRI MONDONG, ANDROS, APE 7, BAFCAT, BEC KILPATRICK, BEN BROWN, BEN OWENS, BEN MARRIOTT, BEN MITCHELL, BILL HOPE, BILLMUND, BIRDHAT, BORJA BONAFUENTE GONZALO, BUNKWAA, BUTTONS, CAM SCALE, CAM WALL, CARLOS BOBI, CARL MORGAN, CHRIS NIXON, CHEHEHE, CHRIS WAHL, CRABLO, CRISIS, CULT DE SAC, DAVID CRAGG, DAVE FOSTER, DEAMZIE, DEANIST, DIGABLE GOODS, DOGFIGHT, EDDY-LOU, ELEVEN, ELSA ISABELLA, FERNANDA PORTO, FIELDEY, GABRIELLE FILTZ, GARETH LLOYD, GEORGE ROSE, GEORGINA ANTON, GEORGIA HILL, GINA KIEL, GLENNO SMITH, GRIZZLE, GRIM FINGA, GWEN WATT, HOUL, HULES, IRENE FELEO, IRESH, ISA FLORY, JAKPOT, JAMES BRISCOE, JACK DOUGLAS, JAK M.C.S, JASON PAULOS, JAYA, JESSE BROCKIS, JIMMY SK, JOE42, JO LEY, JOAO PERES, JON FOYE, JOSH 2000, KALIS, KARL TAGLE, KENTARO YOSHIDA, KEO MATCH, KRISPE, LACHLAN BRUCE, LADY J ADAMS, LEE McCONNELL, LOSOP, LOUIE JOYCE, LUCY IZZARD, LUKE OKAY, LUSCH, MARTIN E WILLS, MATTHEW BOURNE, MATT DAMPNEY, MATT JACKSON, MELLO, MICHAEL LANGENEGGER, MIKE MAKATRON, MITCH WALDER, M-LON, MULGA, MR. story:
What You Are Watching and Why?
The short film above (which we hope you enjoyed), entitled "Star Child," is Wild Maquina's debut project and artistic homage to our cosmic origins. It is a moving portrait painted with the poetry of choreographed dance, experimental film and lighting, spoken word art and pure liberation. After months of work and preparation, it was filmed in the night and early morning of the chilly California desert until the dawn danced in the day. 

Wild Maquina (www.wildmaquina.com) is a new tribe of award-winning and aspiring artists from diverse disciplines and global origins that collaborate on experimental fusion art projects that give homage to the human spirit. Our aim is to create just two spectacular projects each year to inspire ourselves and others to live, love and create without limits or borders. By having a multicultural group, we hope to cultivate a sense of international unity through our work.



What We Need and What You Receive
Star Child and Wild Maquina are all artist self-funded. Any graciously donated funds will go towards two things:

First: Compensating artists for Star Child expenses (time, talent, special cameras, lighting, travel, digital assets, etc).

Second: We want to create our second project for the year! And we want it to be even more imaginative and include more talented artists from around the world. We need more funding to make this happen and share it with everyone!

You Will Receive:
-Our gratitude and love
-$5 donation will receive a private link to download the full HD video version along with an audio file of the spoken poem and music.
-$25 or more donation will receive cool digital prints of Star Child shoot.
-$75 or more will receive digital Star Child prints and digital prints from next project.
-All donators will be sent an e-mail (if they choose) asking them to contribute their ideas for the next project. The person's idea or part of an idea we choose will receive a credit for the project and be an official member of Wild Maquina.

For the first person that lives in the Southern California area and donates $1,500 or more, they will earn a live performance rendition from the Wild Maquina artists of Star Child along with an additional dance performance, two spoken word poem performances, multi-media art showcase and film for one private event (within 6 months of campaign closing)

Why Trust Us?
The leadership of Wild Maquina currently consists of Ponzi, TallTree, and Paulina Pulido, all of whom are award-winning artists. Much of their work is featured in various mainstream mediums, both commercial and non-commercial (click on links to learn more/view their work). As you will see, we have all dedicated our lives to creativity in one form or another and plan to continue and evolve that path with these projects.

Why Does it Matter?
The world is at an interesting point: we have more access to one another through technology, yet we feel less connected. We are saturated with media voices from around the world that ironically don't often say much or speak to who we really are. We believe all this is a symptom of a great distancing from our fundamental nature that we yearn to reconnect with. Mixed-media isn't going away, nor should it, but we want to add our collective voice into these windows where the people of the world are watching, so that maybe they will see back into the beauty of their human spirits.

Can't Contribute Financially? Share some Social Media Sweat!
We are grateful for any help you would like to give, even if it isn't financial! Being that we have this campaign, a video, and a website (www.wildmaquina.com), please share any or all of those with whomever you think will dig it. Thank you!

story:
How important is local art to you? Or local anything? In a world where the handmade is often co-opted by the corporate, 3rd Street Gallery offers a place where local artists and the public can create new relationships and nurture an arts community that is thriving, inspiring and accessible.  Our co-op gallery is on the move and we need your support!

We're being forced to relocate our gallery and need help with this transition. Please consider making a donation to help 3rd Street Gallery extend our legacy to a new generation of art lovers and makers. 

Our history is enough to inspire not only those in the art community but those who love the idea of healthy community, period. Take a look:

  • Artist owned & operated cooperative gallery since 1972.

  • 850+ Solo Exhibitions

  • Hundreds of group exhibitions

  • Thousands of opening receptions

  • 504 member meetings

  • Reviews & features in The New York Times, The Philadelphia Inquirer, CityPaper and more.


Founded in 1972, 3rd Street Gallery is one of the oldest artist run cooperatives in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Our artists pay membership dues to keep the lights on and volunteer many hours to keep our day-to-day operations running smoothly.

We stand for the quality presentation and experience of the visual arts while allowing for experimentation and risk not always possible in commercial galleries. Our primary mission is engaging our public with insightful and challenging creative works and supporting the positive growth of the visual arts in the region.

Our members vary widely in formal education, age and artistic medium which allows us to stay dynamic and continually learn from each other. Every year we throw open our doors to our community and neighborhood, inviting everyone to show their work in the gallery. For 42 years we embraced the collective model to cultivate unique relationships between artists and their community. 

Not convinced? Learn more about us »


Support from the art community is what has kept our gallery thriving for 42 years, and now we are asking for help with our next big endeavor: Relocation!  We have been in our present location for nearly 20 years and need to part ways with our current landlord. This means we need to move and we need to move quickly. We have found a lovely spot in the same arty neighborhood with a new (very nice) landlord and a gorgeous space. 

We ask for your help to:

  • Cover rent in two locations so that the new place doesn't get away
  • Help us with our moving costs
  • Support transitional operation costs of the gallery for one year while we do some structural changes in our membership to ensure our gallery keeps going strong

If we don't reach our goal (inconceivable) we will use funds in the order of the bullet points above.



The artists of 3rd Street Gallery thank you for your support with, what better? ART! Our members have donated original work, prints and the like for you to receive in exchange for your generous donations. It's a win-win! Good job, art lover!

Be sure to check back frequently as these offerings will be updated regularly.



Please share our story with the artists and art appreciators in your life.

  • Share our campaign on your social media pages - facebook, twitter etc.
  • Tell your friends to tell their friends! The more people who can help us, the better.

story:
This is essentially a print pre-order (pre-pre-order??)! Nudist beach is actually a bit out of my comfort zone, so I probably won't be posting any photos of it on my page for a while. I work in a pretty conservative field, so while group stuff will inevitably find its way online through other people's pages, I have no plans to have this costume showcased in my own galleries. But I'd still like my followers to have access to images right away, if they'd like! So that's why I'm doing this pre-pre-order for prints. I'm only going to be printing off one round of nudist beach prints, and they won't be put up in my storenvy, so they're only available through this campaign! unfortunately, putting up an image of the prints here when they come out kind of defeats the purpose, so the prints are gonna be a surprise. but hey who doesn't love surprises right? *O*

(pay no mind to the fundraising goal, that just happens to be indiegogo's minimum!)

*for those of you not familiar with kill la kill, these are not NUDE prints! it's the outfit from the preview photo

story:
Sacred Spaces is a place of spiritual inspiration. Help us create a gallery that reflects our purpose My Name is Anthony Sirios West, I am an Artist based in the foothills of Northern California. I have been given the privilege of curating Art for Sacred Spaces Village at Burning Man 2014. 

 This opportunity is very meaningful to me as I owe the rekindling of my artistic passion to Burning Man and the visionary art community. The purpose of money raised is to create a visionary art exhibit inspiring creativity and spiritual awakening, through an exhibit space carefully designed to showcase some of the greatest art and talent that our community has to offer. The art will create a visionary gathering place for viewers to exchange conversation, vision, and inspiration to fuel cultural advancement. 
 Every contribution furthers this project and helps me reach my goal: to exhibit more of the art we all enjoy and love, and to give more new, up and coming artists a chance to showcase their work. Art showcased through my curated exhibit at Sacred Spaces will have the opportunity to be viewed, explored, experienced, and discussed by thousands of travelers and other Artists from all over the world, as we gather in celebration of Art and creativity at Burning Man. 
The more money I raise the greater the experience can be for the artists and guests. Further, allowing more time and energy that I can dedicate to the creation of an inspiring experience for those who have the privilege to view and enjoy the exhibit. The funds raised will help with expenses related to the creation of this curated art space. These include things such as: transportation to the event, set up, lighting, and electricity. All to bring 30+ pieces of art from 12 different artists, from around the world, to the eyes of countless people in a visionary cultural exchange space.
 *Amounts contributed past our goal of $1000 will work to further offset the costs of bringing this experience to the playa and will enable us to bring more lighting and fuel to allow for more art to be exhibited around the Sacred Spaces Village. 
 PERKS! Brian Paul Smith of fractal alchemy and I have teamed up to bring you all some amazing perks for your contribution. The perks range from one of fractal alchemy's amazing hologram creations to an original painting from me, Anthony Sirios West. Art is an amazing vehicle for inspiring change and spiritual awaking in not only an individual but the entire world. Perks bring this Art to your home while you help me bring these Art works to a global audience. 
 The first time I set foot in the Sacred Spaces Village, at Burning Man, the art brought tears to my eyes. I knew, in that moment that my life would never be the same, and it was my mission to inspire change in the world through my own artwork. Now, I find myself tasked with the creation of the very gallery that brought upon that realization, and I am honored to be able to share my gifts alongside so many other great artists. As many of you have no doubt been to the playa before, you can understand what a challenge bringing something like this out to the Burn can be. However, I am confident in my abilities to overcome any obstacles that I find in my path and bring this inspiring experience to fruition. With the help of our amazing community, this will undoubtedly be an inspiring experience for everyone that has a chance to see it.
 If donating money is not an option for you, I completely understand and would greatly appreciate if you could take a few seconds to share a link to my campaign with friends so it can reach a broader audience. Help me reach and exceed this modest goal of $1,000 and bring beautiful Art more expansively to the World! Thank you for spreading the word, so that we can bring inspiration and beauty to playa yet again.
 You never know who it could inspire to change the world.

story:
I am so excited to start my first artist residency in the mid-west.

ACRE (Artists’ Cooperative Residency and Exhibitions) is a volunteer run non-profit organization based in Chicago. Every summer ACRE offers numerous Artist Residencies in Steuben, WI designed to support and nurture emerging artists. 

I am a multidisciplinary artist and my studio practice focuses on identity, relationships and the Native American experience. I have been estranged from my tribe since my father (through whom i claim my tribal status) was imprisoned for murder. Without my dad I find myself constructing who my dad was and what my culture is. I am interested in the concept that all of my artwork is authentically Indian merely because I am a documented American Indian enrolled in a tribe.

Through this residency I would like to make a collection of beaded “paintings” and mixed media paintings. I am concerned about the relationship of painting and multimedia in my practice. Through this project I would create a bridge and better understand how they relate to each other.  

The beaded paintings would be made from pre-drawn patterns that are then woven on a beading loom with glass beads. I would create paintings combining beads, glue, buckskin and acrylic paints. With these paintings I will play with the illusion of depth and texture, and actual depth and texture. The imagery in these paintings will reference personal photographs of my father and my estranged family.


For more information and images of the incentives please see my blog:


http://noellesbrokeprofessional.wordpress.com/author/noellesbroke/

story:
Stinky Nice  is a performative musical group formed by Adrienne, Phoenix, Marty, Sam, and Cyndi during our Senior year at Rhode Island School of Design. We have each always felt passionate about sound as a creative medium for expression, so through time we naturally came together at school to play and share our sounds. Through a series of living room jam sessions, open mic nights, and shows on and around campus, we began cultivating rich performative and sonic explorations. 

Our sounds have been described as “sonic mayhem,” “rowdy noise,” “crazed,” “dissonant,” “intelligent,” “beautiful,” “lovely,” and “SOO GOOD.” We perform with a mixture of rehearsed songs that soothe your ears and improvised sounds that challenge conventionally clean methods of live performance. We often employ choreographed movements, like belly rolls, to signal a switching of instruments and structuring of our chaos. We encourage audience interaction by leaving instruments and tools out for everyone to play with. We sport fun and goofy costumes that highlight our musical personas. Most of all, we have fun and try to get everyone involved to have fun too. :)

After playing consistently together during the school year, we decided to continue pursuing our passion post graduation with a stinky Summer endeavor!

Thus, the Stinky Summer Fest was born. Or, at least, the idea of it. The ideal goal of the Stinky Summer Fest is to meet a wider audience by traveling across the east coast of the United States in a recreational vehicle and to learn and share the experience of making art with the community.

We plan on leaving from Providence, RI in mid-July, stopping in various locations like music venues, college campuses, houses, parking lots, and public areas for guerilla-style performances. We’ll stop somewhere, set up our instruments and equipment and fire away with power and interactive energy. After we finish playing for the day, we’ll set up a screen on the side of our vehicle and project student works from RISD’s  Film/Animation/Video  department. By not charging fees for attendance to the performances or screenings, we are giving people from many different backgrounds access to our music and arts festival. The journey will be documented through audio and video recordings to be used for a conclusive Stinky Summer Fest Documentary!

We want to see this project come to life because we like the idea that music and movement are universal forms of expression that anyone can be a part of. Creating sound is a communal experience that is not exclusive in any way. How something sounds is simply how something sounds; it is not a good or a bad thing that is loaded with ideology, it is an experience to be shared. Having instruments and materials out for the audience to play is a way of encouraging communal creativity and dissolving the perceived divide between audience and performer -- to share in the creation. Bringing this live experience across the country is a way of broadening our perspectives on music, performance, traveling, independence, and ultimately what it means to be artists living and working in the United States.

While we have a clear idea of what we want to accomplish, we currently do not have a clear idea of how to get it done without funding. This vital component of the project is where you, our beloved donors, can help make this dream a reality.

Funding will all be used for:

✿ Purchasing and insuring a vehicle ($1,400)

✿ Supplying our vehicle with fuel ($500)

✿Purchasing all of our sound equipment, including amplifiers, drums, microphones, and necessary cables ($1,700)

✿Stocking up on food and liquid for 5 people to survive ($750) 

✿ Purchasing a generator for energy and hot plate for eating ($150)

✿Holding some extra money in case of emergency ($500)

✿Making and shipping the awesome rewards 4 u ($200)

✿Accounting for the percentage taken by Indiegogo ($260)

~

We are so thankful to everyone who supports this project! Check out this article and some of our music and videos to see more of what we about u feel me!:

http://our.risd.edu/post/82189060680/on-friday-night-amped-up-students-were-attracted

Some SOUNDS:

Itty - Bitty Boo - Bitty

--->the sp O t . . . .<---

mmmrrrooocccaaapppaaasss (jam mix)

~~~

):)

story:
"I don't know whether the bird you are holding is dead or alive, but what I do know is that it is in your hands. It is in your hands."—Toni Morrison

 

     Hello, my name is Lynne Parks and I’m an artist and curator/organizer in Baltimore City. In this latest project, Birdland and the Anthropocene, artists will be addressing extinction, endangered species, the postnatural, ornithology, and more (I’ve copied my curatorial statement below).  I'm not in the least bit happy about the impending loss of species, but I am excited by the creativity, curiosity and care exhibited in this show which includes visual and sound installations, painting, photography, creative taxidermy, performances, and even a hologram.

     I’m also the Outreach Coordinator for the bird conservation and wildlife rescue organization, Lights Out Baltimore (LOB).  LOB monitors downtown for building collisions during migration.  Light pollution pulls birds into environments full of invisible, deadly glass. Much of my work encompasses advocating for birds via solo and group shows, curatorial projects, and art-generating community workshops.  Recently, I successfully curated Unfriendly Skies I and II at Goucher College and George Mason University.

     For Birdland, the first happy news was securing the space at the historic Peale Center.  It's the first purpose-built museum in the United States. The Peale family is regarded as the first family of American art.  They were artists and naturalists.  They gave us portraits of the founding fathers and displays of mastodon skeletons.  I can't think of a more perfect setting for our exhibition.

     I have also been a long-time birder and over the years I've personally witnessed fewer birds.  The impetus for this show is absence.  That said, we are incorporating a solution center in the museum for the duration of the show.  We have artists who illustrate the dangers of light pollution and buildings design (glass) as relating to birds and building collisions. Two artists have created bird-friendly window film.  We will have joint programming with LOB and Patterson Park Audubon.  

     Community outreach is what makes this real to Baltimoreans.  I'll be giving workshops to city students and with disabled artists at Make Studio--I'm a disabled artist, so I love this partnership.  The workshops will discuss migration, the roles birds play in ecosystems, and threats.  Participants will produce artwork, which will be displayed in the show.  We'll also be collecting stories from Baltimore residents using the Be Here Stories app.  What is your bird story?

     For the duration of the show, weekends will feature performances, as will the opening reception and closing costume party (Halloween weekend).  There will be costumed extinction rituals, concerts, open mic with guest readers, lectures, and more.  Some TBA.  So many will communicate what birds mean to them.  This show is about love.

     I should add that given the seriousness of the show, we offer moments of levity.  Some of it might have something to do with bird poop.

     Surely, with all of this energy we can find ways to mitigate the worst effects of The Anthropocene.  This show feels like a culminating moment to me.  It’s eight years of work and community--arts and bird conservation coming together.  I'm very grateful for this opportunity.

     We need your help!  Shipping and transportation costs from ten U.S. cities and The Hague plus truck rentals in the region add up to $2,725.   We also have an additional $1,000 in materials costs considering we have to paint, drape windows and doorways, make costumes, and hang (hardware).  Parking in downtown Baltimore will cost hundreds of dollars.  This is a year’s worth of work for me, and a curatorial stipend would certainly defray some of my personal costs.  Artists should at least receive $250 stipends.  We work so hard.  Frankly, your contributions will make this show happen and support the creative efforts of everyone involved.  The money we raise will first go toward covering expenses, but will then be shared equitably among the artists.  More money means better deserved payments.  You can also help by sharing this campaign!

     As far as the logistics go, there is a lot of experience collected in this bunch.  These artists have installed many times over.  The Peale has not been renovated and it’s quirky, but Submersive Productions are great friends who have shared their knowledge of the building and they’ve donated a lighting designer.  I’ll be putting out a call for interns from the Maryland Institute College of Art (MICA).

Perks!  Cathy Cook and I will be offering prints and Jonathan Latiano will offer sculptural elements from past installations. 

 

Exhibition hours:

Thursdays and Fridays 6-9pm; Saturdays 12-6pm; Sundays 10-4pm from October 6-29, 2017
Opening Reception, Oct. 6, 6-10 p.m. with performances
Closing Costume Party, Oct. 28, 7 p.m. until late

Saturday programs, Rotating artist talks at 2 p.m.
Oct. 7 Benjamin Andrew, Christina Baal, Chris Siron
Oct. 14  Jieyu Zhang, Lynne Parks 
Oct. 21 Cathy Cook, Elisabeth Pellathy, Nicole Shiflet, Ben Piwowar

Saturday 14 at noon.  Lindsay Jacks, Director of Lights Out Baltimore

Sunday noon programs: 
Oct. 8 Open mic referencing birds. Guest writers Tatiana Nya Ford, Linda Franklin, Jenny O’Grady, Timmy Reed. 
Oct. 15 Dariusz Skoraczwski, Baltimore Symphony Orchestra's Principal Cellist, bird song-influenced selections
Oct. 22 Ian Nagoski, Music Researcher, Early 20th Century Bird Recordings and Bird-Imitations 

Artists:

Divya Anantharaman, Brooklyn, NY
Sandy Anderson, New Orleans, LA
Benjamin Andrew, State College, PA
Christina Baal, Mamaroneck, NY
Amy Boone-McCreesh, Baltimore, MD
Krista Caballero, Takoma Park, MD  and Frank Ekeberg, Trondheim, NO
Ashley Cecil, Pittsburgh, PA
The Center for PostNatural History, Pittsburgh, PA and Ian Nagoski, Baltimore, MD
Cathy Cook, Baltimore, MD
Laure Drogoul, Baltimore, MD
Edgar Endress, Fairfax, VA
Linda Franklin, Baltimore, MD
Anne Geene and Arjan de Nooy, The Hague, NL
Susan Humphrey, Baltimore MD
Ashley Kidner, Baltimore, MD
Jonathan Latiano, Baltimore, MD
Monique Luchetti, Brooklyn, NY 
Jennifer McBrien, Baltimore, MD
Lynne Parks, Baltimore, MD
Elisabeth Pellathy, Birmingham, AL
Ben Piwowar, Baltimore, MD
Jessica Rassp, Baltimore, MD
William Rhodes, San Francisco, CA
Glenn Ricci, Baltimore, MD
Nicole Shiflet, Baltimore, MD
Chris Siron, Baltimore, MD
Andrew Yang, Chicago, IL
Jieyu Zhang, Reading, PA

Extinction Ritual performers, Baltimore:

Kristen Faber
E'tonia Ford
Lynne Parks
Jessica Rassp
Lisi Stoessel
Claire Wayner

Additional performance by Laure Drogoul and the Illuminated Fountain of Extinction TBA.

Taxidermy courtesy of the Baltimore Bird Club’s Nature Museum.


Curatorial Statement:

     Here we are in Baltimore, famously known as Birdland, and I’d like to think we love all of our birds.  Sports teams are part of our identity, but so is poetry, and a diversity of actual birds that by the nature of their existence keep our ecosystems healthy.  Birds provide pollination, seed dispersal, insect control (and thereby disease control), pest control, and more.  If that isn’t enough incentive to be grateful to them, bird watching is a fifty billion dollar industry in the United States.     

     I’ve gathered together artists who consider extinction, endangered species, and the postnatural—organisms that have been intentionally altered by humans. Some artists examine ornithology, the scientific study of birds—some play with the methods involved.  Our technological advances have harmed the natural world in many ways, but how can we use technology to save it?  How does extinction disclose domination and exploitation in political systems? How are birds as symbols used in these narratives? How do we imitate birds and what does it reveal about our perception of them? What is it like to be a bird?

     Consider birds for birds’ sake—they are living dinosaurs, full of beauty and portent, present in every aspect of our culture.  We’ve coevolved with birds and studies suggest that human’s most essential trait—language—is derived from our observations of birdsong.  

     Mostly birds.  That’s this show and my life.  As an artist/curator and volunteer for the bird conservation/wildlife rescue group, Lights Out Baltimore, I’ve dedicated much of the last eight years to advocating for birds.

     Birds are in trouble.  They are disappearing.   The silent spring that Rachel Carson warned us about is affecting regions piecemeal.  The causes include habitat loss, death by free-roaming cats, building collisions, invasive species, pesticides, and more.  A combination of these factors results in a loss of resources.

     In this new geologic epoch, the Anthropocene, natural systems have been affected by human activities and encroachment--evolution, migration, biodiversity, climate, etc.  Fifty percent of bird populations in the United States are likely imperiled and might disappear within a century. 

     I’ve been a dedicated birder for sixteen years.  In the time I’ve spent observing the local habitat, our city, I’ve witnessed the onset of this distressing change.  There are fewer birds.  And yet, there has never been such a swell of interest and scientific inquiry into understanding birds’ physiology, especially their intelligence.  We race to understand what is being lost.

     We ask the community to weigh in on these issues.  In workshops, Baltimore City students will respond with their own art.  We’ll collect bird stories from city residents with the app, “Be Here Stories.”  We’ll engage with local conservation groups. 

     The Peale family included many artists and naturalists, and importantly, their love for these disciplines produced the first purpose-built museum in the United States.  Rembrandt Peale established the first gas light company in America and showcased the new technology here.  Today, we know that light pollution attracts birds into deadly glass environments resulting in collisions, a leading cause of bird mortality. This inadvertent effect reminds us that humans must be careful of our inventions.  We need helpful darkness.

     Considering the Peale’s history, can there be a more ideal site for this exhibition? What ties this all together?  We investigate how the natural world shapes us and how we shape it.  We determine threats and countermeasures in a world that is fast becoming characterized by absence.
