-- Rodney Ewing
 
Words from the curator of USSSA:
"I wish I had Rodney as an art instructor when I was growing up.  He is living proof that the arts are not just an industry to make things "look cool" or to fool you into buying something.  His work compels me.  I marvel at his technique and in a matter of moments I realize--I am immersed in feelings--I have connected with the character in his work.  I find myself relating to an image."
Rodney is an emerging artist to watch--his work has reached a sophistication in recent years that has much to teach us about moving into the 21st century.  Early in our conversations, Rodney and I aligned over an interest in Howard Zinn's seminal work "A People's History of the United States."  I noticed that in addition to being an artist, Rodney is an eclectic historian. He has learned his lessons from books, both fact and fiction, as well as from the stories of the people in his own life.  At one point in our conversation he sounds like a psychologist and, at another, he becomes a social theorist.  In all cases, he is a wondrous human being.  He has learned from the best and the worst of the decades behind us and what may be strictly political for some, is grounded in human experience for Rodney."
As my child grows up, I would love for Rodney to teach him how to draw; how to see the world through another person's eyes, how to appreciate the values and beliefs of "the other," and to learn that mere tolerance is of no benefit to the profound lessons yet to be learned through genuine empathy and respect."
-- m. ryan noble
 
How your donation will help:
Rodney's drawings for USSSA are some of the best examples of the human condition put onto paper.  The subjects include child soldiers and the despair of the assassin mind.  Sadly, these perspectives have not fallen to be obsolete but may in fact be more relevant than ever.  These large drawings will be installed back-to-back and hang from the ceiling such that viewers can witness these art works from either side and from more than one perspective.  Your donation will help afford the materials, shipping, and hardware for the installation of his work.  Any funds beyond his goal will provide Rodney with transportation to promote the USSSA in a town near you!
As an artist with a growing reputation, Rodney's prints are sure to be an attractive perk and a keen investment.  Please share Rodney's project with anyone you know who supports the arts or, more simply, a compassion for others.
        
USSSA
http://www.facebook.com/USSSartists
Thirteen contemporary artists will be forming “a more perfect union” in the month leading up to the Presidential Election, 2012. The project, “USSSA (united secret society of subversive artists),” will feature a highly diverse group of artists; all politically invested in the arts. They are educators, activists and organizers. The artists of USSSA will each create an installation around a theme of her or his choice. Through innovations to the curatorial model, this project becomes a venture where each artist presents a personally relevant perspective and engages the project as a space to work toward equal terms of support, respect and resolution. In bringing a collective voice to the issues that are most important to us, this group of artists will be calling attention to the dynamics of democratic process, documenting our innovative forms of collaboration, and bringing form to the patterns of real and actual change.
 
More USSSA campaigns
Please also visit the campaign page for fellow artist, Christy Speakman.  Her project "Watershed" allows supporters to explore the vanishing Louisiana wetlands through interactive technology.  Thank you for supporting the artists of USSSA!
http://www.indiegogo.com/USSSA-ChristySpeakman

story:
DOWN TO THE WIRE

OUR GOAL IS NOW TO REACH ONE THOUSAND DOLLARS

WE HAVE BEEN ABLE TO BRING THIS IN WAY UNDER BUDEGET.  ALL WE NEED NOW IS $1000 TO BRING IT HOME

We could really use your help.  We have another day or so to raise as much as we can before this campaign ends.

$1000 is all we ask!

 

The Twisted Upright House is one of 35 Structures that will grace Burning Man's Circle of Regional Effigies this year.  An exciting project, it combines the efforts of the North Bay Burners, the SF North Bay Burning Man Northern California Regional network-a living matrix of creative burners that spans the coast from Marin County all the way up to Del Norte County-and Pyroglyphics, a Fire Arts team based in Humboldt County.  

The Twisted Upright House will stand 20 feet tall, with a base diameter of six feet, and will sit off-center on an island 63  feet in circumference.  Tall, slender, and eight-sided, it will stand 1/3 the scale of  its real-world inspiration, but will turn125 degrees from the base to its apex, giving the lighthouse a strong and fluidtwist to its architecture. This twisting will be visually reinforced by an equal shift in its doorway, windows and railings, and punctuated further by the island itself:

The island will be made of driftwood that is laid out in concentric swirls emanating from the lighthouse base and will radiate out to the coast, tracing the layout of the golden ratio, so that the arching lines on its surface will connect with and visually reinforce the twisting corners of the lighthouse.

The island’s elevation will be two feet at the base of the lighthouse, and will slope down  to ground level at its coastline.  Off to one side of the island will stand a small, weathered pier, extending out beyond the coast’s perimeter.  The playa floor surrounding the island will be washed in low-lit blue light to simulate the sea.   We hope that the overall effect will be one of an elegant and gracefully illuminated coastal-scene benevolently manipulated by a greater and mischievous power. 

In the lens’ chamber atop the lighthouse, a slow spinning light will rotate and shine through eight, stunningly detailed stained-glass panels seated 16’ above the playa floor.  The nautical world created by this piece will draw in the viewer, creating a watery respite in the desert, while the light from the tower will act as a beacon for the viewers below to find their way.

We are already over halfway to our goal.  We have raised over four thousand dollars towards the $8500 budget estimated to build our lighthouse and get it out to the playa.  We have what it takes to get the project started, and we will be posting updates as the build begins.

What we need now is the last finishing touches - the lighting, the fire safety and first aid equipment, transportation and fuel costs, and all the little details that make a large burn structure spectacular.  Any funds raised over and above what is needed to directly fund this project will go towards the formation of the new nonprofit North Bay Interactive Arts.

Thank you to everyone who has gotten us this far - we really appreciate all the support from the community.  And don't forget all the fabulous perks!  Original artwork and schwag galore is yours if you contribute to the Twisted Upright House.

Please tell everyone you know!

story:
《日本語はこちら》

Hi. My name is Yuzuri Nagai, and I am a botanical dye artist living in Tokyo.

Journeying into Blue: journeyingintoblue.com

I create natural dye from my organic, home-grown plants. I also grow my own cotton and work with other natural fibers.

 

In spring, I prepare the soil and plant the seeds.

In summer, I harvest the dye plants and dye with brilliant, gentle, elegant colors from nature.

In autumn, I harvest cotton and seeds for the next year.

In winter, I prepare the fibers and spin thread.

 

It’s been such an honor to learn from the rich tradition of ancient Japanese dyeing methods  and work in sync with the rhythm of nature.

 

Exhibition: BEYOND COLORS 

 

I am going to host my very first exhibition “BEYOND COLORS” in Tokyo from April 2nd to 5th this year together with the amazing painter kimi, who is based in the Tohoku area of Japan.

 

The focus of the exhibition is to create a space for visitors to pause and reflect on what’s beyond the colors they see, appreciating the depth of dimension that colors bring into our lives.  My hope is also to do my part to revive the lost art of traditional Japanese plant dyeing.

 

I will also be partnering up with amazing performers to host a side event of music and spoken word (in-person/online *available for participants from overseas,  Japanese/no translation provided). I will also be hosting a botanical dye workshop during the exhibition (in-person only). 

 

The exhibition will be held in Tokyo, but don’t worry! There will also be an online showcase (both in English & Japanese) afterwards, and you can join from wherever you are for FREE! 

 

Why support?

Working with materials from nature is a very time consuming process. It can cost quite a lot to prepare environmentally-friendly supplies too. Not to mention, renting a gallery is expensive as well. So then why am I doing this? Because I believe in ART!! Art is FUNDAMENTAL to our being, and we all need it to become better, deeper and more whole. 

I would love to invite you into this meaningful and exciting project and make this happen together as a team! 

 

What We Need & What You Will Get

The money will be used towards:

  • Half of the gallery rental fee (30,000yen) *Yuzuri's part
  • Miscellaneous cost for the exhibition (captions, supplies to hang the art works, flyer, etc.) (10,000yen)
  • Payment for videographer(s) to make contents for the online viewing (10,000yen) 
  • Equipments needed to host online events  (10,000yen) 
  • International shipping fee to send out thank you gifts (5,000-10,000 yen)
  • Indiegogo platform fee/transaction fee (10,000yen)

       *5% Indiegogo platform fee + 4.4% international transaction fee + Transfer fee 2,750 yen

 

Risks & Challenges

  • Exhibitions are one  of the biggest opportunities for artists to secure their funding for their future work, whether it be through creating a network or selling their art works, or hosting side events. However, due to the pandemic, we will be having the events on a much smaller scale, and the situation might not bring in as many people as we were hoping. However, we are working hard at the moment to make a virtual showcase available as well as provide a platform where people can purchase our works online. 

 

  • Even if we didn’t reach the goal, the exhibition will still happen on a smaller scale and your contribution will be used towards the needs above. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • SHARING is EVERYTHING! You can use the Indiegogo share tool and share this project on social media. *click the "SHARE" button on the top right of this page, it will copy the page URL on your device
  • Follow me on Instagram or Facebook, and stay tuned! I will be sharing sneak peaks of the exhibition before and during!

story:
Short Summary

ENTER THE EXIT is the graduation group 2020/2021 of Contemporary Jewellery and Gemstones at the Trier University of Applied Sciences campus Idar-Oberstein.

We all have traveled from different lands with the sole purpose of transforming matter. Our very diverse cultures and backgrounds derive in a very rich artistic community where materials from eggshell to steel give all kinds of sensory experiences.

Our works examine the intimate and universal through personal themes with emotional intensity and gestural marking, expressed in the medium of contemporary jewellery.

Our aim is to take our graduation works further, promote them in new spaces and reach more people interested in arts, crafts and jewellery.

Until now we have been facing dificulties with bigger sponsors due to the current COVID-19 Crisis and this is why we need your help to make it possible.

What We Need & What You Get

Organizing an exhibition is hard work. Designing graphics, making and editing photos, creating a website, maintaining social media up to date, building furniture and traveling to other cities in order to reach more people. 

We are planning to take part in arts and crafts exhibitions throughout Europe which translate into expenses of over 10,000€

Munich Jewellery Week  ✓

Group exhibition in Luxembourg 

Object Rotterdam 2021 

INTERGEM 2021

Grassi Messe 2021

MK&G Messe Hamburg 2021

Inhorgenta 2022

With this campaign and your help we aim to raise 5,000€. In appreciation for your help you can receive very cool ENTERTHEEXIT Merch.

Totebags // Pins // Postcards

And our deepest gratitude for believing in us.

 

Why help us?

Contemporary jewellery is an interesting crossover between many fields arts, fashion, design and crafts which widens our concept of what jewellery is. Our works campaign against fast fashion and trends, giving value to a wider range of materials many which are not common int the traditional market. At the same time it gives us freedom to use traditional materials like gemstones and precious metals in an unconventional way.

As an artistic medium it gives space to thought and may pass a message.

Challenges

Some of our most anticipated events have been postponed and/or cancelled but we have managed to look for alternatives to such adversities hosting online exhibitions and looking for other interesting events.

If we weren’t to raise the goal sum, we would still manage to attend some of the listed events with our personal funds and the collected aid.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are already very grateful that you are interested in our campaign and that you took the time to read our proposal. We understand that not everyone can help with money but if you like our work, please share the link to our campaign!

We would also love you to follow us on social media :)

https://www.facebook.com/enterthexit

https://www.instagram.com/enterthexit/

http://www.youtube.com/c/entertheexit

story:
Three years ago, CIRCUS Magazine was conceptualized in the bedroom of it’s founder and editor, Bianca Betancourt,in the middle of a notoriously brutal Chicago winter.

 

Always an avid lover and subscriber of magazines, Betancourt soon became frustrated with the lack of true inspiration on the pages of her favorite glossies. She wanted to read stories penned by the likes of Vanity Fair, but also wanted the visual candy of photography masters like Vogue. Not to mention, she wanted stories and visuals that actually related to her age group—there was a big gap between teen magazines and adult fare that desperately needed to be bridged. Millennials want inspiration too.

 

Six months later, circus-magazine.com was born. With the training behind her internships at Chicago SPLASH Magazine and the Chicago Reader, Betancourt took what she learned about the day to day operations of a magazine and brought together eager and passionate artistic individuals who simply wanted to create—and create is what they did.

Today, CIRCUS is known as the digital destination in Chicago when it comes to art and culture. CIRCUS has consistently showcased trending and undiscovered artists in Chicago and beyond and how their work and mindsets intersect with the politics of fashion, music and more today. We have 15,000 monthly readers across the globe—spanning from Mexico, South America, The UK and more aside from the United States—who routinely check in on our latest feature stories and profiles.

Since the very start of CIRCUS Magazine, it has been a long term goal to put our stories and content into print. Print is  a magazine’s true form, and in a world full of SEO headlines and clickbait, though we’re thankful for the massive expansion of the internet for showcasing our work for so long, it’s time to place our timeless stories and interviews on paper where they belong.

 

Earlier this month, members of the CIRCUS team traveled to Los Angeles, California for our biggest feature stories yet. We’re in the midst of finalizing stories for our premiere print issue now, and we’re planning to release the final product to the world by the end of September. The stories and visuals a part of this magazine will be our best work, our proudest work, and ultimately be a physical representation of our limitless capacity to create. We never want to stop doing this, but in order to continue, we need your help.

 

We want to spark questions of pressing social issues, entertain, and inspire individuals across the world. Many efforts and selfless contributions has made CIRCUS the unique magazine it is today. We kindly request a donation that will be  distributed towards the printing costs for the premiere print issue of the magazine. Paper and printing is expensive, and this easily the most expensive endeavour we've ever done, but the product that will end up at our readers' doorsteps will inspire far past the normal interest shelf life of any other magazine. 

Your donation will be the foundation for all the great things the magazine has yet to encounter and our appreciation for your help goes beyond words!

Let art live, let art thrive.

story:
Snapshot

MILS is a Sydney-based non-for-profit organisation that was founded by Adriano Rosselli in 2009. Until July 2016, the directors of MILS ran a gallery space - MILS Gallery - out of an unoccupied shop-front located on Randle Street, Surry Hills.This campaign is to raise money for the independent production of an art book documenting the exhibitions held at MILS Gallery throughout the 7 years of its existence.


The Importance of the Fringe Art Book

Works of art often last forever, or nearly so. But exhibitions themselves, especially gallery exhibitions, are like flowers; they bloom and then they die. It is important that they be recorded, because exhibitions – especially contemporary art exhibitions -establish and administer the cultural meanings of art. Part spectacle, part socio-historical event, exhibitions are the primary site of exchange in the political economy of art. Since the advent of cheap colour-printing in the 1960s, art books and exhibition catalogues have become the most common way for institutions to memorialise these events, in an assemblage of colour-printed photographs, and writing about the artist(s) and works depicted. These books are intended as contributions to scholarship as much as books that are likely to appeal to many general readers. Importantly, they constitute a form through which artists, curators, or anyone at all, can engage with art history outside of the academy. But, in 2016, exhibition catalogues remain the preserve of institutions that can afford them; there is a vast disconnect between the contribution that fringe galleries and artist-run initiatives (ARIs) make to local art culture, and their means of recording those developments for art history. What we need is support for a new category of art book: one that could be published independently, by emerging curators. Crowd funding and social media have opened up new possibilities for emerging artists and curators to realise themselves whilst remaining outside of ‘the institution’; enabling ARIs to self-publish their own catalogue books is incredibly important for the preservation of a genuinely alternative and experimental art culture.

About MILS Gallery

MILS Gallery began when Rosselli, at the age of 21, decided to occupy the empty ground floor space of his building, a triangular-shaped apartment block, where he was living on the third floor. The co-directors of MILS were his friends - fellow students at the National Art School - and the space was initially used to showcase the work of other practicing art students. At the time, the streets just east of Sydney’s Central Station were home to a number of artist-run initiatives; MILS co-existed amongst First Draft Gallery, Chalk Horse, China Heights, Serial Space and Gaffa Space.

While some of the inner-Sydney ARIs have continued successfully in new locations, supported by government grants, it was inevitable that most would close as soon as their directors’ capacity to run them fell short. Out-of-date websites do not suffice as a record - the life of these galleries, its artists, and exhibitions, have vanished into the personal memories of the people who participated in their existence.

MILS matured alongside its artists, developing a stable of regular contributors who had grown up with the gallery. With the time, energy and thinking space that this provided, the MILS directors became increasingly interested in seeking out and exhibiting international artists from non-Western cultures. Over the years, MILS introduced their inner-Sydney community to contemporary output from Iran, Syria, Inuit Canada, Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Ghana, and China, amongst others.

In July, 2016 the building that MILS Gallery occupied was sold to property developers as part of a greater construction project that includes the buildings where Gaffa and Artspace once resided.

The Book Project

Rosselli, MILS’ primary director, saw the tragedy in allowing the ephemera of artworks, photographic documentation, exhibition invitations and texts, to languish invisibly and incoherently within the algorithmic trenches of the MILS website, his personal computer hard drive, and in the storage spaces of his apartment. Since the closure of the gallery in July, he has set about gathering, editing, and compiling all documentation of MILS’ exhibitions into an intimate, historical catalogue of the artists’ work. The book is being produced in collaboration with two of MILS most esteemed artists, Eko Bang Bang Wisnu (Indonesia) and Huw Lewis (Sydney), who each designed a cover. He has now completed a digital version of the book that contains over 450 images of artworks, by over 120 artists. The published book will feature an introductory essay by Sydney-based writer Anna Georgia Mackay, and several essays by other writers and artists who were affiliated with the gallery.


Our Request

Costs:

We will be printing onshore with Inscope books who have quoted us $4,860.00  for 80 copies.

story_txt:
SnapshotMILS is a Sydney-based non-for-profit organisation that was founded by Adriano Rosselli in 2009. Until July 2016, the directors of MILS ran a gallery space - MILS Gallery - out of an unoccupied shop-front located on Randle Street, Surry Hills.This campaign is to raise money for the independent production of an art book documenting the exhibitions held at MILS Gallery throughout the 7 years of its existence.The Importance of the Fringe Art BookWorks of art often last forever, or nearly so. But exhibitions themselves, especially gallery exhibitions, are like flowers; they bloom and then they die. It is important that they be recorded, because exhibitions – especially contemporary art exhibitions -establish and administer the cultural meanings of art. Part spectacle, part socio-historical event, exhibitions are the primary site of exchange in the political economy of art. Since the advent of cheap colour-printing in the 1960s, art books and exhibition catalogues have become the most common way for institutions to memorialise these events, in an assemblage of colour-printed photographs, and writing about the artist(s) and works depicted. These books are intended as contributions to scholarship as much as books that are likely to appeal to many general readers. Importantly, they constitute a form through which artists, curators, or anyone at all, can engage with art history outside of the academy. But, in 2016, exhibition catalogues remain the preserve of institutions that can afford them; there is a vast disconnect between the contribution that fringe galleries and artist-run initiatives (ARIs) make to local art culture, and their means of recording those developments for art history. What we need is support for a new category of art book: one that could be published independently, by emerging curators. Crowd funding and social media have opened up new possibilities for emerging artists and curators to realise themselves whilst remaining outside of ‘the institution’; enabling ARIs to self-publish their own catalogue books is incredibly important for the preservation of a genuinely alternative and experimental art culture.About MILS GalleryMILS Gallery began when Rosselli, at the age of 21, decided to occupy the empty ground floor space of his building, a triangular-shaped apartment block, where he was living on the third floor. The co-directors of MILS were his friends - fellow students at the National Art School - and the space was initially used to showcase the work of other practicing art students. At the time, the streets just east of Sydney’s Central Station were home to a number of artist-run initiatives; MILS co-existed amongst First Draft Gallery, Chalk Horse, China Heights, Serial Space and Gaffa Space.While some of the inner-Sydney ARIs have continued successfully in new locations, supported by government grants, it was inevitable that most would close as soon as their directors’ capacity to run them fell short. Out-of-date websites do not suffice as a record - the life of these galleries, its artists, and exhibitions, have vanished into the personal memories of the people who participated in their existence.MILS matured alongside its artists, developing a stable of regular contributors who had grown up with the gallery. With the time, energy and thinking space that this provided, the MILS directors became increasingly interested in seeking out and exhibiting international artists from non-Western cultures. Over the years, MILS introduced their inner-Sydney community to contemporary output from Iran, Syria, Inuit Canada, Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Ghana, and China, amongst others.In July, 2016 the building that MILS Gallery occupied was sold to property developers as part of a greater construction project that includes the buildings where Gaffa and Artspace once resided.The Book ProjectRosselli, MILS’ primary director, saw the tragedy in allowing the ephemera of artworks, photographic documentation, exhibition invitations and texts, to languish invisibly and incoherently within the algorithmic trenches of the MILS website, his personal computer hard drive, and in the storage spaces of his apartment. Since the closure of the gallery in July, he has set about gathering, editing, and compiling all documentation of MILS’ exhibitions into an intimate, historical catalogue of the artists’ work. The book is being produced in collaboration with two of MILS most esteemed artists, Eko Bang Bang Wisnu (Indonesia) and Huw Lewis (Sydney), who each designed a cover. He has now completed a digital version of the book that contains over 450 images of artworks, by over 120 artists. The published book will feature an introductory essay by Sydney-based writer Anna Georgia Mackay, and several essays by other writers and artists who were affiliated with the gallery.Our RequestCosts:We will be printing onshore with Inscope books who have quoted us $4,860.00  for 80 copies.

story:
CAM: A NEW ARTS AND CULTURAL SPACE

Common Area Maintenance is a new 3000 sq. ft community gallery space in the heart of downtown Seattle, designed to offer affordable workspace and direct community access to art. Our goal is to amplify Seattle's artistic vitality, and we need your support!

CAM will welcome you and the rest of the community to celebrate arts and culture via enriching events, such as performances, readings, video installations and pop shops. We will deepen community involvement in the arts through the use of our storefront as a public art gallery and regular open door hours—promoting consistent exposure to the inner workings of our artistic ventures!

Your contribution will provide the community and emergent artists with opportunities for art engagement, and connect artists with their art by offering working-class artists affordable space where they can create and have curatorial opportunities. Our space will be able to provide up to 10+ artists with personal and collaborative workspace, and offer curatorial and creative involvement for artists in the community at large.

We are looking to generate enough capital to begin renovating the space. To close our funding gap we need to raise 20,000.00 dollars!

2125 2nd Ave. Seattle, WA 98121

HOW EXACTLY WILL YOUR SUPPORT BENEFIT THE PROJECT?

All of the money you donate will exclusively be used to renovate the building:

  • $950- An updated ADA compliant bathroom, so everybody, without exception, will have equal access to the space! 
  • $1,820 - Electrical system updates: Let there be lights!
  • $6,500 - We are cutting a hole in the floor and adding an alternating tread staircase down to the basement! This will give us an extra 1,000 sq. ft of space to work with while keeping everyone connected.
  • $5,300 - An amazing wall to separate the gallery space from the work environment. The wall will be jointed and rest on over-sized casters, allowing it to fold up for open-space events! 
  • $2,550 - We get to patch and paint the walls, too! Remember, this old building needs a lot of love!
  • $2,500 - Permits
  • Any money raised beyond our goal will go toward further renovation!


Just a few of the holes we have to patch to make this building happy again! 

THE LIGHTS ARE GETTING BRIGHTER IN BELLTOWN: Our new arts community will be in the great company of several longstanding and incoming local businesses, including: Theatre Schmeater, Object, Crybaby Studios, The Holocaust Center, and Suyama Space among many others. 

HELP US KEEP THE ARTS ALIVE & WELL IN SEATTLE!

During a time when many artists’ workspaces are closing or becoming financially inaccessible, many artists are forced to halt production or search for affordable work space outside of the city--ultimately bleeding Seattle of its artistic vibrancy. 

Please support us in the creation of an affordable art space that benefits the whole community by keeping art local! 

                                    5x3.5 foot internally lit sign, to be used as an alternative exhibition space.  A unique opportunity for exposure and interactivity! 

OUR DESIGN WILL PROMOTE INCLUSIVITY ON MULTIPLE LEVELS!

We want to break art out of isolation: Through our events, open door hours, and storefront gallery, we hope to mend the gap that can exist between artists and the surrounding community. We aspire to unmask the creative process by encouraging community interaction with working artists.

Our simultaneously intimate and open workspaces will enable communal opportunities such as, collaborative idea making, skill sharing, and access to tools and materials—all of which multiply artistic possibilities!


Open Formatted Workspace



HELLO

My name is Timothy Firth. I am a full-time working artist here in Seattle, WA. My personal practice is strongly directed by interactivity, participation and the belief that accessibility leads to greater forms of expression—the development of Common Area Maintenance is in part guided by those keywords and will help lay the foundation for the work we do together in the future.

 As Seattle inevitably continues to grow and change, I believe that individual artists and arts supporters are the ones with the power to promote change that will keep our cultural programs and organizations alive.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please, even if you can't donate, make sure to share this campaign with other people who are dedicated to maintaining arts in Seattle. Arts and Cultural spaces are what make a city livable—art is the beat of a community's heart. Let's keep Seattle alive and vibrant!


FUNDING PERKS

#1 - Don't Just Simply Crumple and Give Up, by Toby Liebowitz.  Scrollbook print.  12 inches x 30 ft. 



#2 - Untitled, by Daniel Mitchell.  Watercolor and ink on paper.  12 x 17.5 inches.



#3 - Floating Shapes, weaving by Caitlin Emeritz.  Organic cotton, cashmere, cotton chenille.  5 x 9.5 inches.  



#4 - Stone Bangle, by Faris.  High Polish Brass.  Made in Seattle. 


#5 - Necklace, by History + Industry.  Brass, and wooden beads, sourced in New York.  Handmade in the US.


#6 - Djuna Overalls, by Leitmotif.  Unisex overalls for kids ages 4-5 years old.  50% cotton, 50% lyocell.  Sustainably made in San Francisco. 



Edit(or) [Pre-Construction], by Fayen D'Evie.  Acrylic Spraypaint on board.  7.5 x 12 inches. 

Marble Movie, by Toby Liebowitz.  Graphite and watercolor.  9.5 x 8.5 inches.



 

Necklace by History + Industry.  Ceramic and wooden beads, sourced in New York.  Handmade in the US.



Untitled, by Daniel Mitchell.  Ink on dot matrix paper.  33 x 9.5 inches. 



Untitled, by Daniel Mitchell.  Ink on dot matrix paper.  22 x 9.5 inches.


Composition 12, by Rachael Lang.  Digital print.  20 x 20 inches framed.



Familiar Faces 6, by Jean Nagai.  Correctional Fluid on Paper.  20x25 inches.



A Study on AO, by Jean Nagai.  Correctional fluid on paper.  20 x 25 inches.



Nice Things, by Jean Nagai.  Correctional fluid on paper. 14 x 18 inches.



Untitled, by Nich McElroy.  Digital Print.  20x24 inches. 




Magic Dreams, by Alder Suttles.  Silver Gelatin Print.  10.5x12 inches (including frame).



Untitled, by Darin Shuler.  Ink on paper. 11x14 inches.



Where did you come from?, by Toby Liebowitz.  Graphite, watercolor, and gauche.  7.5 x 17.5 inches.



Cushman, by Jean Nagai.  Correctional fluid on paper.  22x28 inches.



Untitled, by Daniel Mitchell. Watercolor on paper.  9x17.5 inches.



Untitled, by Daniel Mitchell. Watercolor and Ink on paper.  12x18 inches.


Shaman on Rollerskates, by Stacey Rozich.  Gouache and Watercolor on paper.  7x7 inches.



Mound, by Jean Nagai.  Correctional Fluid on Paper.  22x28 inches. 


       

Dune ring in Sterling Silver, by Erin Considine, available in ring sizes 6,7,8. 



Necklace by History + Industry.  5/8th inch green jade, brass, ceramic beads sourced in New York.  Handmade in the US.  



Don't Have a Cowabunga, by Darin Shuler.  Ink and Watercolor on paper.  12x16 inches.


      

Untitled, by Carlos Ruiz.  Illustrated photograph.  12x18 inches.

story:
I come from a town where there is not a strong art community. I know I have a great talent I just need the help now to get it exposed.

As a child I was always interested in art and the idea of creating something from nothing.  My first year in wood shop at Bellevue Sr. High 2003 was the first time I worked with a wood burner.  This was your basic burner tool but for some reason I felt in my element but at the time I was also a three sport athlete and followed football.  In 2005 I became a Tiffin Dragon and attended Tiffin University. In 2008 I had back surgery which was the end for my football career.  After graduating Tiffin University in 2010 with a BBA I still was lost and unsatisfied with my career path in Hospitality... it wasn't until 2011 I began marketing myself by taking on jobs for people pertaining to art.  Slowly I created a name and my reputation began to grow. My former boss Matt Strecker bought an old bar and flipped it. Later calling it Bier Keller and one of the main attraction was a twenty five foot bar top I wood burned, taking 250 hours.  I continued to pursue the path as a pyro graphic artist because I know I have much more to offer. I put no limits on THRE350 Graffix!  Let the movement begin!!!

What We Need & What You Get

The funds raised will be going towards tools needed to help improve my art, specifically Orbital Sander, Dewalt Planer, Single Bevel Compound Saw, 20V Max Lithium Combo Kit, 18 Guage Finish Nailer, as well as funds to hire a graphic designer and programmer for my website template (which I have hand drawn), to help get my art out to the public. Again, I come from a town where there is not a strong art community. I know I have a great talent I just need the help to get my  art the exposure it needs to make it my career.

Our perks are unique and one of a kind. The t-shirts offered are going to be through this indiegogo only. The art involved will also only be available through this indiegogo. Many of what is being offered will not be offered again. Through these perks you will be helping my art grow to the next level and get to be a part of my growth.

The Impact

Aside from getting my art out to the world I would like to be able to affect people in a positive way through my art. I would like to donate some of my pieces to different charities to help them raise money through auctions. I think Rob Drydek has started something great with the Drydek foundation, I would like to be involved with programs like that to use my talent to impact those that need help. I feel very confident that I could help make a positive impact on peoples life's. Perhaps one day even starting my own foundation getting kids into exploring their artistic abilities.

Other Ways You Can Help

Other ways you can help - My goal is to get my art out to the world, so even if you can not make a financial contribution you can still help me by just sharing me with your friends. Help me get my art out to the world. I really feel like I have a talent that can not just go to waste, but I need you guys to help ensure that does not happen. I have a facebook page, facebook.com/thre350graffix, that is amazingly at 3,000 fans already. So don't feel bad if you don't have the money to contribute. Word of mouth is priceless, so please let people know about me and my indiegogo link!

need help. I feel very confident that I could help make a positive 
impact on peoples life's. Perhaps one day even starting my own 
foundation getting kids into exploring their artistic abilities.Other Ways You Can HelpOther ways you can help - My
 goal is to get my art out to the world, so even if you can not make a 
financial contribution you can still help me by just sharing me with 
your friends. Help me get my art out to the world. I really feel like I 
have a talent that can not just go to waste, but I need you guys to help
 ensure that does not happen. I have a facebook page, facebook.com/thre350graffix, that is amazingly at 3,000 fans already. So don't 
feel bad if you don't have the money to contribute. Word of mouth is 
priceless, so please let people know about me and my indiegogo link!

story: You know you want to give me money so I can have a wizard permanently tattooed onto my body.
story_txt: You know you want to give me money so I can have a wizard permanently tattooed onto my body.

story:
I am an artist and have been making art for over 43 years. At this time in my life I am short of funds and having trouble buying art supplies and paying bills, not unusual for artists everywhere. I would use any funds hopefully rich in bounty  to buy supplies and pay bills including my rent. I make sculptures, paintings, collages and drawings, and I have an extensive resume and my art is in the collection of The Guggenheim Musuem, The Whitney Musuem and The Hirshhorn Museum among others. I have received 3 National Endowments, 2 Pollock Krasner Grants and The Gottlieb grant, so any funding will be going to an artist who has proven himself.

 

As I said I would be using most of the money for my rent and buying art supplies.

story:
Hi! I’m Luciana, a.k.a. Viiolaceus! You may know me as the artist behind Holobunnies and some other indie games. I currently live and work as a frelance game artist in São Paulo, Brazil and soon moving to Montréal (Longueiel) - Canada.

This month I had a lot of unexpected happenings and bills to pay such as rents (yes, plural) my ticket, visa fees, vetenarian, my anxiety and adhd meds for the next 6 months, bills and other things - whcih left me with no money left to pay for my dog, Pixel, airplane ticket - that I have to pay until november 6th)

 

Pixel is very special for me - my best friend and support  in thought times. I couldn't possibly move without her; That's why the campaign.

What am I offering back? Commissions at special prices and for personal use only ♥ In honor to my pup Pixel it's going to be pixel art what I'm offering :)

 

(If you are a patron at patreon, want a special request or want to contact me for game art or commercial work, send me a e-mail at viiolaceus[@]gmail.com)

 

Thank you so much ♥

Lu

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of six students from IESA Arts & Culture Paris, all of us coming from different countries of the world: Brasil, China, Germany, Italy and Russia. 
We started this project a school-driven project, but with time it became a lot more: it became a project that is so close to our hearts that we decided to create a crowdfunding page to make it possible at all costs. 

The topic of the exhibition is very hot nowadays, and it's time for us too to speak out: we present nine contemporary artists who suffered from sexual abuse or that are very close to the subject and that produced artworks to overcome it.

Making this exhibition possible will help an entire community to have the tools to understand partriarchy a lot better and to start fighting it actively.

 

What We Need & What You Get

As we would like to make this a charity event too, we kept the costs as low as possible, to be able to give all the profits to an NGO that works with this topic*. The goal of this campaign is not enough to make it a beautiful and complete exhibition, but it's enough to make it happen. 
More specifically, the funds will go to the following:
- the venue
- the transportation of the artworks
- the installation material
- the printing material

* If you are a French resident and you want an invoice for tax purposes (donations are deductible from taxes), please contact us directly before donating on this crowdfunding page!

We designed perks to give to the donors with an exclusive illustration designed by Silvia Bocchero, but we don't know if we can afford the production of them. We decided to give everything we can to the NGO, so you can be sure that no money is wasted. If we exceed the goal we set here we will produce the perks and they will be sent to all of you!

If we don't reach the goal, the exhibition will happen anyway, but it will have less impact and less professionality. We are investing a lot too in this and we hope to make it worth it!

 

The Impact

Many people are already believing in us: the NGO we are working with, the non-profit Led By Her, that will be our partner, the venue, the artists. Everyone is doing this almost or completely for free, collaborating with us for a very good cause. Some artists are willing to donate some works to raise money to donate to the NGO. 
You can certainly feel how dear this topic is for all of us, and how urgent it is to adress it in active ways. We believe that art can heal wounds, maybe we can help healing this wound of the world.

 

Risks & Challenges

One of the biggest challenge for us is to find sponsors: given the delicate topic, many companies (too many, actually) don't want to be associated with it, believing that it will have a negative impact on their marketing strategies. We have faced many nos, just because of this. This is why we need this crowdfunding to work!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, this is perfectly acceptable! You can help by sharing this campaign, or by sharing the event in the different social media. People have to know about this!

story:
Artisyn Studio & Cafe are located in Tujunga, CA. Artisyn Studio officially opened in April 2015, offering classes in art, dance, music and more to children and adults in Los Angeles. Artisyn Studio also provides a space for events including a weekly open mic, weekly figure drawing party, music nights and more! Here's a fun video from one of our first classes in the Studio:



We can still use a couple more items in the studio, specifically dance mirrors and ballet barres. For these 2 items we need approximately $2000.

Simultaneously we are working on opening up Artisyn Gallery & Cafe. Originally we were just planning on opening up Artisyn Gallery & Cafe, and we would have been doing our lessons (music, dance, art, etc.) in the Cafe. Once we started this process, we realized that the Cafe space would not be enough accomplish everything we wanted to with our various art lessons, so we leased a second space next door for the Studio, allowing us to do everything we want to not only support artists but to teach and grow new artists! We built out the Studio space first and are now fundraising solely for the Cafe.

For the Cafe the architectural plans are done, but we still need electrical/mechanical plans, the permits and the clearances for the cafe, which will cost approximately $10,000-$12,000 total.

Our goal for this campaign is $5000, but we will accept as much as possible to cover more and open as quickly as possible. The faster we get the funds raised, the faster we can open to provide this amazing cafe and gallery for you guys. So please keep up the good work with contributing and sharing!

Summary:

Artisyn (pronounced just like "artisan") Gallery & Cafe is Artist Synergy's first physical location, because what's better than coffee & art combined? (that's a rhetorical question). At Artisyn Gallery & Cafe, artists will be able to take art lessons, music lessons, dance lessons, writing lessons and any other type of art lesson you can think of. We will also host open mics, art shows, musical performances, etc.

Artisyn will be where ALL artists can come to sit and have a cup of coffee while working on a painting, or while writing their latest novel or a new riff for a song. It will be where artists can express themselves through their art and help other artists grow as a community. It will also be a great place for parents to bring their children for various art lessons, or just to hang out with a group of friends.

We signed the lease for our beautiful location on Foothill & Commerce in Tujunga, CA! Our new home for the gallery/cafe is at 7206 Foothill Blvd, Tujunga, CA 91042. Artisyn Studio is located at 7208 Foothill Blvd, Tujunga, CA 91042.

One of our additional goals is to raise the Sunland/Tujunga community up through art and community activities including gatherings, meetings and activities provided at Artisyn Gallery & Cafe.

What We Need & What You Get:

This is the Cafe space currently (we're starting from scratch):


Opening a cafe is very expensive. We would like to do this while getting into as little debt as possible, therefore we are funding it ourselves and asking for some help from our friends and family.

We have a TON of awesome perks and rewards including free credits to the cafe, artwork, merchandise and much more.

The Impact:

Los Angeles has a HUGE base of artists, including many who do art as a "hobby" but have no clue how to take it to the next level. There are also artists who don't know how to start performing live shows or how to get their art shown in a gallery, or how to get their book published. Artisyn will be there to help any artists to take their art to the next level or take their next step in business.

In the direct community we will use art to raise people up, motivate people, give people a purpose. We will have events to give back to the community including our annual RAKart day (Random Acts of Kindness with Art) and many more events and fundraisers we will be doing.

We are working to create an artistic renaissance, starting locally and eventually branching out across the US and then across the world.

Risks & Challenges:

Our biggest challenge is not having enough capital. Our plan to solve this is by asking our friends and family to help out with the funds as a group. We will also be hosting pre-opening art shows, coffee parties and more to raise any additional funds needed, plus I'm working my own butt off as an artist making and selling paintings, jewelry and everything else :)

The Studio is also currently raising income and once operating at full capacity will be producing enough income to cover the rent for both units, the operating expenses for Artisyn Studio, and potentially additional income to help build out the Cafe. 


Other Ways You Can Help:

Even if you can't contribute financially, please, please, please share this far & wide and ask your friends and family to help out. Also if you are local you can always contact Marcy at artisyncafe@yahoo.com if you are interested in becoming involved in Artisyn by helping with any set-ups/renovations, teaching an art class, etc.

story:
About Me

My name is Benjamin "Blue" Jackson. I have been a miniature painter for over 10 years as a hobby and working for other miniature painting companies.  In the past two years I have been doing commission work to launch my own business, Loharl Studios. More and more commissions are coming in, but I am running out of studio space.

This campaign is to help me get a better and larger work space. Better lighting and a larger space will allow me to produce a better product with quicker turn around.

What We Need & What You Get

We are setting our goal at $2000, that will get all of the deposits paid, so we can move in to a new place as soon as possible. Even if we do not get the full goal it will put a dent in what we need to come up with.

Don't forget if you pay in to $1000 perk you will get a full year of FREE commissions. I don't care if is 1000 Orks or 1 large dragon as your center piece for you Pathfinder campaign. I WILL PAINT IT FOR FREE.

The Impact

This would mean the world to me and my family because not only will it let my professional life grow, but my family as well.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, Like, Subscribe! We know there are a lot of people out there living paycheck to paycheck, and we understand. If you can't donate towards my new studio space, please take the time to share this on Facebook, subscribe to my YouTube channel, or follow me on Twitter.

Thank you all for you time and help.

                                                Sincerely,

                                                             Blue and Sara

story:
Short Summary

We believe in young women artists’. 

We believe they have the power to change the world.

Girl Empire was founded in 2013 emerging from an vital need to support young women artists’ between the ages of 18-25 both in creating a network of support, but more importantly providing a real, tangible, and accessible avenue for young women to get their art in front of the world.

Young women visual artists, writers, filmmakers, and musicians around the United States have the opportunity to submit pieces of work that will be included in the "Girl Empire Emerging Young Women Artists' Collection," a showcase of collective anthologies to be distributed under the Girl Empire umbrella.

In addition to getting their art in front of the world, Girl Empire creates a dynamic collective network in which young women can receive mentorship, peer support, and ongoing opportunities to expand their artistic reach through both social media and an interactive website. 

The nature photographer in rural Vermont can share a cup of coffee over Skype with the documentary filmmaker in the Pacific Northwest. The musician in Denver can expand her reach to Miami when she connects with a peer who was featured in on the same Emerging Young Women Artists Album. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $8500 which will help launch the first volume of collective anthologies of young women artists under the Girl Empire umbrella. 

$8500 will fund the production and distribution of:

  • Volume One: Written Anthology of Young Women Authors (Softcover book) (Qty. 1,000)
  • Volume One: Young Women Musicians (CD) (Qty. 1,000)
  • Volume One: Young Women Filmmakers (DVD) (Qty. 1,000)
  • Volume One: Young Women Visual Artists (Coffee Table Art Book) (Qty. 100)
  • The Perks:
  • Whatever funds are raised, we will produce and distribute as many Girl Empire Collective Volume One Anthologies as possible with the funds we receive.

The Impact

It’s no surprise that more and more, we hear about arts funding slowly disappearing in our communities. It is being left up to us to nurture young artists and for young women who have passion, talent, and desire to be recognized, Girl Empire is a vehicle for bringing those passions, talents, and desires to the forefront.

Our goals are simple:

1.  Help young women to get their art in front of the world.

2.  Create a powerful community of support where young women are recognized and acknowledged for their artistic accomplishments.

Be ready. Passionate, talented, young women artists’ are here and ready to showcase their art. With your help, their art will have no boundaries and will inspire many along the way. 

Risks & Challenges

This has never been done before. We are throwing the net wide. We are striving to support young women who want to get recognized, but a public anthology of this size has never been released. There are a lot of moving parts and logistics in the submission process of the art mediums, the production, and distribution.
Our goal is to work with partners who stand for the work and the mission of our social enterprise even though tracking down those partners may be difficult.

We are brand new and creating our brand as we go. Our biggest challenge is building the infrastructure to support this project and at the same time support young women doing amazing and stunning work. The goal always is to support young women first. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Calling Young Women Artists! Are you a young woman artist? We would love to hear from you and explore the possibility of featuring your work in an upcoming anthology! Contact us at info@girlempire.com
  • Be Part of Our Community at Girl Empire We are looking for passionate individuals who want to become part of our community through web development, social media projects, and community ambassadors throughout the United States. Contact us at info@girlempire.com
  • Share this project with others in your community!

story:
Esercizi di Visione sono esercizi performativi che si realizzeranno nella città di Roma e non solo, pensati e dedicati personalmente a chi sottoscrive una donazione.

Questo progetto artistico nasce dall’elaborazione della mia futura mostra personale “From Here to Eternity” che si terrà nello spazio no-profit AlbumArte a Roma, dal 18 di Febbraio al 1 di Aprile.

Intro

Invitata a realizzare una mostra nello spazio di AlbumArte, ho pensato ad un progetto che risponda alla domanda: può lo spazio performare o possiamo noi performare lo spazio?  Ho dunque elaborato alcuni esercizi di visione, dedicati esclusivamente allo spazio di AlbumArte. I fondi raccolti serviranno a sostenere parte delle spese di produzione della mostra.

Gli Esercizi di Visione qui proposti sono invece dedicati a te che mi sosterrai.

Se accetti, ogni esercizio ti mostrerà come guardare intorno a te e la città attraverso il racconto di un modo e un tempo diversi di percezione.

Allora, la prendi la mia mano?


Chi sono

Chiara Mu |Nata a Roma nel 1974. Diplomata nel 2001 in Scenografia all'Accademia di Belle Arti di Roma ed in Fotografia nel 2002 alla scuola E. Rolli di Roma, ha vissuto a Londra per 10 anni, ove ha conseguito il diploma biennale di Master in Fine Art al Chelsea College of Art and Design. Chiara Mu opera esclusivamente nell'ambito di interventi specifici su luogo e/o situazione, utilizzando installazioni, performance e video come modalità preferenziali di lavoro. Si definisce una ‘time-based artist’ che abita in modo specifico spazi e tematiche, creando strategie relazionali tra luogo, oggetti e presenza del corpo, sua e dei visitatori. Intende intervenire in modo intimo e provocatorio sulla qualità del tempo di fruizione di chi esperisce il lavoro, mettendo in discussione il ruolo stesso del visitatore ed il suo posizionarsi rispetto all’opera. Ha collaborato negli anni con diverse realtà underground e noprofit inglesi ed italiane, tra cui “Cambridge Artworks Gallery” a Cambridge (UK), “Five Years Gallery” e Yinka Shonibare “Guest Projects Space” a Londra e “Condotto C” a Roma. Ha poi collaborato con la Galleria “Edieuropa-Qui Arte Contemporanea” a Roma e “CIAC” Museo di Arte Contemporanea di Genazzano (Roma). Ha prodotto performances site-specific per il Comune di Venezia ed il Comune di Milano ed e’ stata artist resident in Cina (Studio 493 Yunnan), esibendo il suo lavoro a Pechino e a Kunming. Ha condotto il workshop “Installazioni & Performance. Una pratica site-specific” presso l’Accademia di Belle Arti Di Bologna e numerose lezioni seminariali sul suo lavoro, sulla Performance Art e Installation Art – sia in italiano che in inglese – presso università e accademie tra le quali: Royal College di Londra, Yunnan Art University in Cina, John Cabot University, RUFA, Accademia di Belle Arti di Roma e Università La Bicocca di Milano.

Il C.V. completo qui: chiaramu.com


Concept

Chiedere donazioni e offrire in cambio esercizi di visione - da compiere attraverso indizi ricevuti digitalmente, telefonicamente o semplicemente camminando insieme - è il mio modo di connettere il concetto di valore espresso dall’offerta di denaro al concetto performativo nell’arte contemporanea.

Mi interessa esplorare qui un metodo per affermare una dignità economica che la performance, intesa come avvenimento relazionale e live, sembra ontologicamente e storicamente non avere se non attraverso l’offerta della sua documentazione fotografica, supporto video o testuale.

“L’unica vita della performance è nel presente. La performance non può essere salvata, registrata, documentata, altrimenti farebbe parte del circuito delle rappresentazioni della rappresentazione: una volta fatto questo percorso diventa qualcosa di diverso dalla performance.”

“Unmarked: the politics of performance”- Peggy Phelan 1993


Campagna

Questa campagna di crowdfunding mira a sostenere l’arte Italiana attraverso un percorso di ricerca per la realizzazione di un’opera d'arte effimera nelle modalità ma non nel contenuto. Il sostegno economico diventa fondamentale ai fini della creazione, sia concettualmente che concretamente.

I sostenitori potranno entrare in relazione con me artista  durante il processo di creazione delle opere, vivendone direttamente il senso e la modalità, accettando di esercitarci insieme a guardare i contesti che ci circondano con altri occhi.

Il crowdfunding è uno strumento per finanziare e dunque rendere possible un tipo di arte, detta “time-based”, perché non è veicolata dalla produzione di oggetti ma dalla produzione di tempo e spazio. E’ una modalità artistica non sufficientemente sostenuta dal sistema del mercato dell’arte attuale.

Questa campagna dunque non propone manufatti che si possono portare a casa, da contemplare o rivendere. Il capitale preso in esame qui è umano e ciò che si offre è un contatto, una relazione one to one, un modo intimo di condividere tempo e spazio esercitando lo sguardo  sul mondo.

La mostra presso AlbumArte illustrerà nelle modalità e nelle forme scelte la realizzazione di un medesimo percorso, legato però alla scoperta e alla lettura di una dimensione interiore invece che esteriore.


Obiettivi

Il tuo supporto economico sarà utile a:

- sostenere le spese di esposizione finale della mostra;

-  realizzare un progetto di web documentary per raccontare cosa sia realmente avvenuto nello spazio di AlbumArte una volta conclusasi la mostra: dunque sostenere economicamente la  realizzazione delle riprese, il web design e la postproduzione di tutto il materiale digitale necessario (video, fotografico, di testo).

Si puo’ dare di piu’?

porta questa richiesta con te, in giro, comunicala e postala dove ti sembra più utile! Fai sì che io possa esercitare la visione anche di altri!


ENGLISH VERSION

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Exercises in Vision are performative exercises, designed and dedicated to those who sign a donation for me,  which will take place mainly in the city of Rome but not only.

This art project originated  from the process of elaboration of my next exhibition "From Here to Eternity", to be held in February at the non profit space “AlbumArte” in Rome.

Invited to have an exhibition in the new space of AlbumArte, I decided to create a project in order to deal with this recurrent question of mine: can the space perform or can we perform the space? I then developed some exercises in vision, specifically  for AlbumArte and the raised amount  will support part of the production costs of the show.

The Exercises in Vision proposed here are, instead, dedicated to you, asking for your support.

If you accept this aesthetic relationship with me, each exercise will show you how to look at the outside and the city through exploring another time and another perception of what surrounds us.

So, would you you take my hand?

Asking for donations and offering in return exercises in vision –through clues that you will receive digitally or by phone or by simply walking together – it is my way to connect the concept of economic value to the practice of Performance Art.

I am interested in exploring a method of applying an ‘economic dignity’ to Performance Art; when it is taken as a relational and live event, in fact, it seems ontologically and historically not a sustainable form of profit, except  when it is subjugated to be sold as photography, video, documentation of any kind, texts...

This crowd funding campaign aims to support the Italian Art by helping the realization of a complex work of art for the exhibition. The aimed support becomes essential for the artistic creation, both conceptually and in practice.

Supporters are allowed to enter into a relationship with the artist during the process of creation of the works by having a direct experience of the artist's practice; just donating and receiving the chance of experiencing together a new way of gazing the world.

The dynamics of crowd funding seems very suitable to finance "time-based" art, which is not aesthetically conveyed by the production of objects but by the production of time and space. This campaign therefore does not offer objects to collect. The capital needed here is the “human” kind and what is offered is a relational experience, a one to one encounter, sharing time and space while discovering a new perspective to look at the world together.

The exhibition will illustrate how this process relates to the space of AlbumArte, not revolving around the outside space as proposed here but dealing with an inner one.

Your support will be essential for:

- Bearing the costs for the realization of the exhibition;

- Realizing a project of web documentary to show what really happened in the space of AlbumArte after the end of the exhibition: therefore financially supporting the realization of the shooting, the web design and post-production of all the digital material needed (video, images, text ).

CAN  YOU DO MORE?

TAKE MY HAND!! Share this request of mine  with other people, allow me to exercise the vision of many others and many more!

EUR 10 Credits in the project and a hug when you will join us  to the show!

20 euro / Instructions by mail for you to find, in order to experience a special place

(Rome / Milan / Bologna / Florence / Trieste / Venice)

30 euro / Guided tour - of clues left by me in public places - to find yourself in an unexpected place  of Rome

50 euro / Guided phone tour - for as long as necessary - to lead you to a special place in Rome

100 euro / half an hour together: exercises in vision for two in the Flaminio area... would you take my hand then? (Rome)

200 € / 1 hours together: exercises in vision for two, discovering an unexpected place in Rome

400 € / exercises in vision for two, at breakfast, along the shimmering river  in Rome

500 € / 1 afternoon together, exercises in vision for two in the urban area (Rome)

1000 euro / day time: exercises in vision for two in the city  of Rome

1000 EUR / An afternoon of exercises in vision for two,  in Florence or Bologna or Milan or Venice or Trieste.

1500 euro / A night of exercises in vision for two in Rome, while the sky and all the lights are changing. 

2000 euro / day time and night time in Rome, 1 afternoon and 1 night or 1 night and 1 morning to exercise together, holding hands and overthrowing  every meaning of things.

3000 € / A whole day (day time and night time) in the city that you want! I will be able to show you something unseen as well!!

dall’elaborazione della mia futura mostra personale “From Here to Eternity” che

mi sosterrai.

story:
Bound for the Bray

  • My name is Bill Wilkey and my website is wilkeyarts.com. I am graduating from the University of Missouri with a Master of Fine Arts degree in Studio Arts with an emphasis in Ceramics.  What a mouthful. Graduate School was a formative experience, unfortunately it hasn't provided much income for the last three years.
  • Recently, I was very fortunate to have been selected to participate in a year long artist in residency at the Archie Bray Foundation for the Ceramic Arts in Helena, Montana. The residency begins this fall, and we will be moving out there at the end of July. This is an exciting opportunity to further my career with this residency.  
  • Buy a perk, get a pot!  We're not looking for handouts, Bill is happy to make work for the extra income we need to get to Montana!

What We Need & What You Get

  • Moving truck + fuel = $3000
  • Getting settled in a new city, finding income, etc = $1500
  • Indegogo fees and shipping of perks = $500
  • Your donation = your very own Bill Wilkey pot.  See images of perks on the gallery page.
  • Remember, indiegogo will let me keep a lesser percentage of the raised funds if the goal is not met. 

The Impact

  • Being a resident at The Archie Bray Foundation is an extreme honor, and past residents go on to become professionals in the field.  (Whether it be as a teacher, studio artist or otherwise.)  Knowing people like you had a hand in helping with this process would mean a lot to my family and I. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are not able to purchase a perk, you can help my family and me by sharing this fundraiser by word of mouth, email, or social media.
  • Indiegogo does a great job at making it easy to share, and spread the word. The more people know, the more they can help.

Thanks so much!

Thanks so much!

story:
We are a group of friends scattered across Northern California, New York City, and Germany, who wanted to create an interactive work of art, a social sculpture, that embodies the kind of relational intelligence that we believe describes the cosmos.  That's why we call our art car The Cosmic Conversation:  a bee is a conversation amongst flowers, and a flower a conversation amongst bees.  In our co-emergent intelligence, we are greater than the sum of our parts, both as individual beings and as local and global communities.  Each individual piece is necessary in its uniqueness, and at the same time inseparable as a part of an interconnected, coextensive whole.  The gorgeous rainbow within our giant bee’s belly is an immersive experience that reflects the nuanced spectrum of possibility within us all.  Our bee’s head is a giant lotus flower, because when the hive needs a queen it makes one (and any of us have this potential), and yet our enterprise is also headless and nonhierarchical.  Everyone has a chance to lead, and everyone has a chance to follow.  Oh yeah, and it has 20” mirrorballs for eyes and a mirror cone stinger.  Duh! 

We want to welcome tired, thirsty, hungry, sleepy, hot, cold, maxed-out burners and neighbors into our comfortable, cushy, restful, and beautiful rainbow chillspace conversation pit when it is on playa, or at a local more family-oriented festival or social justice event beyond the Black Rock Desert. 

 

Semi-technical specs: 

The Cosmic Conversation is built on a 1970 deuce-and-a-half troop carrier (M35A2).  We removed the cab and windshield and the troop bench seats from the bed, and bolted six pillars of square-stock steel to the bed to support a custom-built dome that we built by hand out of 3/4" steel tubing.  Over the dome, we’re securing hardware cloth panels covered in ~12,000 silk flowers and ~10,000 addressable LEDs.  The flowers and LEDs on the outside of the dome create the stripes of a honey bee.  Inside the dome, the flowers create an ombré rainbow, an opulent shade structure to our welcoming chillspace, offering both containment and permeability.  At any one time our project has a capacity of about 15 - 20 people, depending on how cuddly they’d like to get.  The truck bed will covered in a super comfy padded rainbow faux fur carpet we’ve sewed and installed.  We’re welding giant wings out of rebar, with a pulley inside that our passengers can use to make the wings flap.  

We’re upgrading the electrical system by adding a second alternator and bank of batteries to power the lights, wings, and six-speaker high efficiency sound system which we are building, without any generators.  The engine is multi-fuel (v cool!) and we run biodiesel.  In addition, all electrical requirements are met through an on-board battery bank which is recharged by the alternators, so the project is near carbon-neutral.   We will have playa-worthy sound and light running solely off the same biodiesel engine that propels our mystical flower sculpture — a self-contained technorganic mini-utopia!

Fabrication has already begun; you can check out our progress on fb, Instagram @cosmicconversation or on our website: http://www.cosmicconversation.net

Now you have the opportunity to be part of The Cosmic Conversation’s rebirth process.  With your participation and donations, you can help turn our dream into a reality!  

 

We still need some funds to bring this project to its full potential, and support from this crowdfund will go directly to:

  • Programmable LEDs and a few more controller chips so that we can light it up real bright, so you feel the buzz, like a real bee

  • Miscellaneous building supplies (steel conduit, steel square stock, rebar, baling wire, hardware cloth, etc.) so that our bee will shine but won’t fall apart on us (or anyone else)

  • Approaching-carbon-neutral technical upgrades, including the electrical system, adding a second alternator, two banks of deep-cycle batteries, a hand-built high efficiency sound system, and DIY low voltage lights

  • Holographic lamé to finish sewing giant lotus petals for her lotus head

  • ~6,000 more silk flowers (for a total of ~12,000), since she’s twice as big as the first time we built her 

Our main hurdles right now, are funding and people power. We need funding, so we can continue ordering things like LEDs, their controlling computers, parts of our sound setup, hardware, and additional silk flowers and lamé.  We have a wonderful crew of enthusiastic volunteers, but could always use more help, so if you’re interested in supporting us but can’t do so financially, please reach out and join us in crafting, fabrication, or simply admiration, enthusiasm, or spellcraft from afar ;-).  Please share our project with friends, family, and folks who might be into it!  Indiegogo makes it super easy to share on social media. 

With love and gratitude,

Tickle, Touch, Charcuterie, Green Fig, Little Antlers, Mullet, and the entire Cosmic Conversation team

cab and windshield and the troop bench seats from the bed, and bolted six pillars of square-stock steel to the bed to support a custom-built dome that we built by hand out of 3/4" steel tubing.  Over the dome, we’re securing hardware cloth panels covered in ~12,000 silk flowers and ~10,000 addressable LEDs.  The flowers and LEDs on the outside of the dome create the stripes of a honey bee.  Inside the dome, the flowers create an ombré rainbow, an opulent shade structure to our welcoming chillspace, offering both containment and permeability.  At any one time our project has a capacity of about 15 - 20 people, depending on how cuddly they’d like to get.  The truck bed will covered in a super comfy padded rainbow faux fur carpet we’ve sewed and installed.  We’re welding giant wings out of rebar, with a pulley inside that our passengers can use to make the wings flap.  We’re upgrading the electrical system by adding a second alternator and bank of batteries to power the lights, wings, and six-speaker high efficiency sound system which we are building, without any generators.  The engine is multi-fuel (v cool!) and we run biodiesel.  In addition, all electrical requirements are met through an on-board battery bank which is recharged by the alternators, so the project is near carbon-neutral.   We will have playa-worthy sound and light running solely off the same biodiesel engine that propels our mystical flower sculpture — a self-contained technorganic mini-utopia!Fabrication has already begun; you can check out our progress on fb, Instagram @cosmicconversation or on our website: http://www.cosmicconversation.netNow you have the opportunity to be part of The Cosmic Conversation’s rebirth process.  With your participation and donations, you can help turn our dream into a reality!   We still need some funds to bring this project to its full potential, and support from this crowdfund will go directly to:
Programmable LEDs and a few more controller chips so that we can light it up real bright, so you feel the buzz, like a real bee
Miscellaneous building supplies (steel conduit, steel square stock, rebar, baling wire, hardware cloth, etc.) so that our bee will shine but won’t fall apart on us (or anyone else)
Approaching-carbon-neutral technical upgrades, including the electrical system, adding a second alternator, two banks of deep-cycle batteries, a hand-built high efficiency sound system, and DIY low voltage lights
Holographic lamé to finish sewing giant lotus petals for her lotus head
~6,000 more silk flowers (for a total of ~12,000), since she’s twice as big as the first time we built her 
Our main hurdles right now, are funding and people power. We need funding, so we can continue ordering things like LEDs, their controlling computers, parts of our sound setup, hardware, and additional silk flowers and lamé.  We have a wonderful crew of enthusiastic volunteers, but could always use more help, so if you’re interested in supporting us but can’t do so financially, please reach out and join us in crafting, fabrication, or simply admiration, enthusiasm, or spellcraft from afar ;-).  Please share our project with friends, family, and folks who might be into it!  Indiegogo makes it super easy to share on social media. With love and gratitude,Tickle, Touch, Charcuterie, Green Fig, Little Antlers, Mullet, and the entire Cosmic Conversation team

story:
Chi Siamo:
La ADEI-WIZO (Associazione Donne Ebree d'Italia) offre sostegno alle famiglie vulnerabili, indipendentemente dalla loro nazionalità, origine o religione, ed è  impegnata sin dalla sua fondazione nella promozione della condizione femminile nella società.


La Adei-Wizo opera in Italia dal 1927 ed è affiliata alla WIZO , una ONG laica, apolitica,  impegnata nell'azione sociale al servizio di donne e bambini in Israele sin dal 1920.

Il Nostro Progetto:
"Arte per la Pace" è una mostra itinerante di 35 dipinti che sarà ospitata in otto Paesi ed arriverà in Italia, a Roma, il 18 Ottobre 2015.
I dipinti della mostra sono nati dalle mani di un gruppo di donne ebree, cristiane arabe, musulmane e circasse residenti ad Afula, a Nazareth e in altri villaggi circostanti. Le donne, tra i 17 e gli 80 anni, sono originarie della Lituania, di Umm-Al-Fahm, di Tiberiade, della  Romania, di Nazareth, di Isfahan, dell' Argentina e delle montagne del Caucaso.

Il gruppo di donne e' nato nel Dicembre 2013 e, da allora, si riunisce due ore alla settimana con Sheila, insegnante di pittura, e David, il direttore del centro WIZO di Afula , per dipingere l'ulivo (simbolo di pace) e per condividere storie di vita vissuta e prelibati piatti fatti in casa afferenti alle diverse tradizioni.

Da questo gruppo e' nata una prima Mostra inaugurata presso la Galleria Comunale di Afula e il Centro Culturale Francese di Nazareth.


Attraverso l'Arte, le Donne dell’Ulivo  sono magnificamente riuscite a costruire un mondo di tolleranza, amicizia e condivisione.


Il Nostro Obbiettivo:
Il nostro obbiettivo è portare la Mostra in Italia  per "importare" attraverso l'arte quel messaggio di condivisione, tolleranza ed amicizia che il gruppo di donne di Afula è riuscito ad esprimere nonostante le tensioni che permeano la vita israeliana. 

Il loro approccio ci riguarda tutti: rivela un "altro" possibile.
Il vostro contributo sarà prezioso per aiutarci a realizzare questo nostro desiderio.

Come Utilizzeremo i Soldi Raccolti:
I soldi raccolti verranno destinati alle spese di viaggio e di soggiorno di quattro Donne del gruppo dell'Ulivo, del direttore del Centro di Afula e dell'insegnante di pittura, i quali, durante la mostra, racconteranno agli ospiti la loro esperienza. 

Dettagli Logistici:
La mostra avrà luogo a Roma e sarà composta da 35 dipinti di altrettante artiste del centro Wizo di Afula. 

L'inagurazione è prevista per il 18 Ottobre 2015, presso lo spazio espositivo Sala Maranga. Qui accoglieremo le artiste assieme al direttore del Centro Wizo di Afula e alla direttrice del laboratorio di pittura.

L’ingresso alla mostra sarà gratuito.

Dettagli sulla Mostra:
Ogni dipinto sarà corredato da un pannello che racconta la storia dell'artista, le sue speranze, il lavoro presso il laboratorio ed uno spaccato della loro vita quotidiana.

La mostra sarà accompagnata dalla pubblicazione di un catalogo d'arte sponsorizzato da Kichka, autore di fumetti e vignettista politico membro del Cartooning for Peace.

La mostra ha iniziato il suo viaggio nel Novembre 2014 ed ha attraversato la Francia, precisamente a Mulhouse, dove l'Associazione Wizo locale ha curato e inuagurato la mostra presso il Temple Saint Etienne.
All'inaugurazione hanno partecipato 18 delle donne artiste, orgogliose di  parlare del loro progetto e del  loro messaggio di pace.



Video di Presentazione:
