story:
I'm Alessandro Beber, a 24-year origami artist and designer.(https://www.flickr.com/photos/30452866@N06/)

Some of my recent works were accepted to be included in the Bridges-2016 exhibition in Finland next August, during this amazing conference about the connections between Math and Art (http://gallery.bridgesmathart.org/exhibitions/2...)

Unfortunately, at the moment I cannot afford such a travel, and being not a student anymore I cannot access the scholarships. Therefore, I decided to try believing in people generosity, and I'm offering some of my works here for that purpose.

Participating to the conference would allow me to meet and share ideas with a great number of Math-Artists, as well as exhibiting my works there, attending the talks and getting new inspiration and ideas for further improving my work!

The money raised through the campaign will cover the travel and participation costs:
  • €250 for convention participation
  • €400 for travel
  • €500 for 1-week accomodation and food

Please, help me make this dream real! I'm curious to discover what developments can take my works after attending Bridges 2016 in person!

Thank you for your support!



10-16-30€ or more: origami Art postcards

Receive one-two-five different, signed origami Art postcards, displaying a beautiful picture of some of my original works. Signed on the front, blank on the back.


50€ or more: "trapped!"

Receive an original modular origami hypercube, folded and signed by the author! Measuring approx. 5-7cm (edge), 9-12cm (standing). Folded from high quality papers. Available folded from tracing paper (white) or "elephantenhaut" paper (1-color or 3 random colors), at your choice.


€100 or more: 1-star or 1-cube tessellation

Receive an original tessellated origami star or cube, folded and signed by the author! Measuring approx. 13x15cm. Folded from high quality "elephantenhaut" paper. I will try to meet your color preference.


€500 or more: an original artwork at your choice!

Receive one original origami tessellation artwork, folded and signed by the author for you! Choose one design among the available ones shown in the picture. Measuring between 17x20cm and 25x30cm. Folded from high quality papers. I will try to meet your color preference.

story:
Hi! My name is Josh Whittaker. I am a recent graduate of UNC School of the Arts. I have been making ultra low budget movies for the past few years and have finally decided to take the next step in my filmmaking journey. My senior year script "Looking for Andrew" is something I'm incredibly passionate about and have wanted to make for years. It's a great story that deserves to be told in the most artful, professional way possible. It is a coming of age story that is unique, relatable, and honest. A group of childhood friends return home after graduating college to discover that one of their own has mysteriously gone missing. They have one lead, and decide that during their last summer together that they are going to embark on a cross country road trip to find him and rekindle their friendships. 

Moving up from the Canon 7D, hiring 'real' actors and a 'real' crew will allow us to make a heartfelt film with incredible potential on the festival circuit. 

We are raising a portion of our budget through indiegogo. Our total goal is $20,000. This will go towards paying cast and crew members a modest salary, equipment rentals, post-production, props, festival entries, gas (road trip movie), and food.

We are offering a wide range of perks - tickets to the local private screening, DVDs, custom paintings of geese, bridge lessons, posters, private visits on set and more.

If we don't reach our goal we will still make the movie but it will have to be scaled back accordingly. This may change the shooting schedule, equipment, and post production, but we are going to do everything we can to make the best movie possible.

This film takes a deep and honest look at friendship, love, and sex. The characters transition into adulthood and their fading friendships are something we have all gone through and will continue to go through. This will be a very unique film that explores many deep, interesting, relatable characters.

Our last movie made it into the NYC Independent Film Festival. Director of Photography Ben Zschunke has a lot of experience and produced "The Polar Bear Club" which has done well at various festivals throughout the country.

We will have a very small crew, with a tight shooting schedule and a portion of our shoot will be on the road. Ben and I have both worked on various projects with little to no crew. In my previous few films I have acted as the 1st and 2nd AC, director, script supervisor, producer, sound guy, gaffer, camera operator, director of photography, and actor - typically at the same time. To have a professional support group to take over these duties and allow me to just direct will lift a huge burden.  

Every penny helps, but even if you can just share the word we would really appreciate it.

Thanks!

story:
Overview

We are creating 2,000 special edition cereal boxes--Donald O's and Hillary Puffs--as parody art for the upcoming presidential election. We will make only 2,000 cereal boxes, 1,000 each for Hillary Puffs and Donald O's. We envision the boxes being similar to those that AirBnB created as parodies for Obama and McCain in 2008. See this link for additional details: https://www.airbnb.com/obamaos

What We Need & What You Get

As a result of your $20.00 contribution you will get one collector's cereal box for the campaign of your choice. 

  • $20 gets you 1 box of Hillary Puffs, or 
  • $20 gets you 1 box of Donald O's 

The Impact

By purchasing one of our limited edition boxes you will be helping us garner support for our art work, and will generally help us get our Cereal Art business off the ground.  We also plan to contribute a small portion of net profits to the respective parties' national committees (maybe 1%). 

Risks & Challenges

We're in the process of finalizing the artwork and design of the boxes, and have identified a custom printing. Now we just need some preorders to get the ball rolling. We're highly confident that we will be able to execute on this mission should we receive an adequate number of pre-orders (say 1,000).

story:
Short Summary

For my Spring 2016 BFA Exhibition, I presented a body of work titled "Menagerie". It consisted of over 130 5x7" color photographs. Now, I am doing a short run of t-shirts as a promotion for the show and as a fun thing for my art to be on!

What I Need & What You Get

The upfront printing of the shirts is close to 300 for 20+ shirts , so how we will do it is you will reserve your shirt on IndieGogo for 16$ You will also include your shirt size. If you want more than one, please pay the correct amount and include that size as well. 

For now, the shirts will come in one color (white) with the designs shown above on the front and back. 

Deadlines

This campaign will end Friday, April 22 to allow printing time before the beginning of May. Whether we have reached the goal or not by then, I will still use the money and get people the shirts they reserved no matter what,

Shirt distribution will likely take place the first week of May.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't buy a shirt, no problem! Any contribution would be awesome, but telling your friends and sharing this link is the absolute best way to get these shirts out there!

story:
Short Summary

We’re extremely excited to open our doors and foster life changing experiences throughout the community. Our rare skillset has developed overtime into something extraordinary and we cannot wait to project this through our work. Despite our ambitions, there are several cost associated with opening such a multidimensional space and we would really appreciate your help in making this possible. All contributions will be used in funding one or more items from the list below. 

•    Required Licenses / Permits
•    Insurance 
•    Marketing / Advertising Material 
•    Software
•    Furnishings / Renovations 
•    Equipment 
•    Event Funding 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help us by getting the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Commission us for your next project! 

What is Dope Overdose Studios?

Dope Overdose: an overdose on originality, innovation, and creativity.

  • Clothing (C3)

1/3 of our studio serves as a showroom to the lifestyle brand, Dope Overdose. Created in 2010 by Devin Johnson, the brand started as an online network that provided a platform for visitors to intake the creative things going on around them. Since then the apparel line has grown in quality and innovation, now holding a dominant stance in the Atlanta streetwear community. With the inspiring message of the brand the motivational spirit of the owner, Dope Overdose continues to wow creatives with its hazardous foundation and free aesthetic. Dope Overdose's pieces are designed as an everday reminder to live dangerously free beyond the means of our structured lifestyles.

  • Creativity (C2)

Being built by three distinctively different visionaries, Dope Overdose Studios is a creative power house. Creating from multiple artist perspectives allows us the ability to formulate concepts that both encompasses the vision of our clients and creatively holds their own amongst competition with the market. Idea generation, creative direction, graphic design, and photography are at the top of our talents; at Dope Overdose Studios there are no limits to what we can do. From individual commissions to corporate branding identity, it is our mission to provide our clients with timelsess creations that stand out amongst the world.

  • Community (C3)

Our studio provides a unique atmosphere for innovative urbanites to work and play. Dope Overdose Studios' in studio photography set up, workshop, and lounge area are just a few of the highlights within the space. Through event curating, community service initiatives, and our mentorship program; Dope Overdose studios will create life changing experiences, revive, and help give new meaning to the city of Atlanta one individual at a time.

Our Work 

Photography

Graphic Design/ Branding

Merchandise Design

story:
PROJECT & IMPACT:

Retrato de un Paisaje / Portrait of a Landscape first took place in 2016 at the Shirley Fiterman Art Center at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, NYC. The next iteration of this project will be an exhibition and parallel events held at the Eduardo Sivori Museum in Buenos Aires, Argentina in September of 2018. In doing this, we are establishing a continued exchange between emerging artists in Buenos Aires and New York that can happen on an annual basis. This campaign will help us facilitate this exchange by making sure all of the sixteen artists can be present for the exhibition in Buenos Aires to engage with the public at opening events and through presentations, discussions, and studio visits.

The exhibition also coincides with Art Basel Cities in Buenos Aires, a week-long art programming initiative focusing on the Argentine art scene within an international context, during which various events will be hosted at the Sívori Museum. The exhibition also forms part of ‘Festival de la Luz- Encuentros Abiertos’, a series of exhibitions, conferences, discussions and events about photography in Buenos Aires. Both of these collaborations will bring additional audiences to this project and provide a broader context for the public.

 

'Portrait of a Landscape' at Shirley Fiterman Art Center, NYC, 2016.

NYC and BA artists together at the opening of 'Portrait of a Landscape' at Shirley Fiterman Art Center, NYC, 2016.

One of the gallery spaces at the Eduardo Sívori Museum in Buenos Aires where we will be exhibiting 'Retrato de un Paisaje', this September 2018. 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET:

With your donations to help fund this project, we can ensure that all 16 artists along with their artworks can travel to the exhibition and be present for the opening and participate in talks, dinners, studio visits, and other events with the public and local context in Buenos Aires. These moments of dialogue and collaboration between the artists will be key to establish real and necessary connections between the art communities in both cities. We will also direct the funds raised to create a catalog for the exhibition that will serve as an important tool to disseminate information about this exchange, and help promote the project for future years as it continues on. With your help, we can further cultivate international awareness around the rapidly growing contemporary art scene in Buenos Aires, and highlight the connections between the work of emerging artists in both cities. 

In gratitude of your generous support, artists participating in this project have contributed artworks to this campaign. Please find below notes from the curator and organizer Claudia Cortínez with a complete list of the exhibiting artists below.

 

FROM CURATOR:

In the practice of photography, the terms portrait and landscape have come to define not only the medium’s most traditional genres but also the standards of composition when viewing or making an image. Retrato de un Paisaje / Portrait of a Landscape reframes these conventions and draws a line between continents; it brings together artists from New York and Buenos Aires to propose a meeting point between the photographic and physical world. The exhibition plays with reformatting the photograph as an object where memory and materiality are at the forefront, each artwork unfolding its parameters of viewing as a physical experience that speaks to the geographic and social contexts in which it was made.

 

Some of the participating artists from both NYC and BsAs during the exhibition in 2016.

 

PARTICIPATING ARTISTS:

Rodrigo Alcon Quintanilha / BsAs

Erica Bohm / BsAs

Ayelen Coccoz / BsAs

Claudia Cortinez / BsAs

James Hyde / NYC

Myeongsoo Kim / NYC

Barney Kulok / NYC

Estefanía Landesmann / BsAs

Samuel Lasso / BsAs

Carolina Magnin / BsAs

Esperanza Mayobre / NYC

Alva Mooses / NYC

Libby Pratt / NYC

Martyna Szczesna / NYC

Pedro Wainer / BsAs

Max Warsh / NYC

 

-----

 

PROYECTO & IMPACTO:

Retrato de un Paisaje es una exposición que propone un intercambio de miradas sobre cómo los artistas de Buenos Aires y NYC interpretan sus entornos a través de diversos usos de la fotografía. La primera exposición tuvo lugar en 2016 en el Shirley Fiterman Art Center del Borough of Manhattan Community College, y la próxima fase de este proyecto tendrá lugar en Buenos Aires, acá en el Museo Eduardo Sívori, en septiembre de 2018. Al hacer esto, estamos estableciendo un intercambio continuo entre artistas de Buenos Aires y Nueva York que pueda ocurrir anualmente. 

La muestra también coincide con Art Basel Cities en Buenos Aires, una iniciativa de programación artística de una semana de duración centrada en la escena artística argentina en un contexto internacional, durante la cual se realizarán diversos eventos en el Museo Sívori. La exposición también forma parte del Festival de la Luz- Encuentros Abiertos, una serie de exposiciones, conferencias, debates y eventos sobre fotografía en Buenos Aires. Ambas colaboraciones traerán audiencias adicionales a este proyecto y proporcionarán un contexto más amplio para el público.

Con sus donaciones para ayudar a financiar este proyecto, podemos asegurar que todos los 16 artistas junto con sus obras de arte puedan viajar a la exposición y estar presentes en la inauguración y participar en charlas, cenas, visitas a estudios y otros eventos con el público y el contexto local en Buenos Aires. Estos momentos de diálogo y colaboración entre los artistas serán claves para establecer conexiones reales y necesarias entre las comunidades artísticas de ambas ciudades. También dirigiremos los fondos recaudados para crear un catálogo para la exposición que servirá como una herramienta importante para difundir información sobre este intercambio, y ayudar a promover el proyecto para los próximos años a medida que continúe. Con su ayuda, podemos cultivar aún más la conciencia internacional en torno a la creciente escena del arte contemporáneo en Buenos Aires, y destacar las conexiones entre el trabajo de artistas emergentes en ambas ciudades. 

En agradecimiento a su generoso apoyo, los artistas que participan en este proyecto han contribuido con obras de arte a esta campaña. A continuación encontrará notas de la curadora y organizadora Claudia Cortínez y arriba se puede encontrar una lista completa de los artistas expositores.

--En la práctica de la fotografía, los términos retrato y paisaje han llegado a definir no sólo los géneros más tradicionales del medio, sino también los estándares de composición a la hora de ver o hacer una imagen. Retrato de un Paisaje re-enmarca estas convenciones y traza una línea entre continentes; reúne a artistas de Nueva York y Buenos Aires para proponer un punto de encuentro entre el mundo fotográfico y el físico. La exposición juega a reformatear la fotografía como un objeto en el cual la memoria y la materialidad están en primer plano, cada obra de arte desplegando sus parámetros de visualización como una experiencia física que habla de los contextos geográficos y sociales en los que fue realizada.--

story:
The Project

In the summer of 2011, I met with the Dr. Christine Soler, pediatric oncologist of the CHU- L’Archet-2 Hospital in Nice and began discussing the possibility of providing a collaborative art experience to the patients of the children’s ward. What came of this was the idea to have the children come up with a new name for their ward and design a mosaic mural that would depict the new name. Since that time the idea has grown into an international collaborative art effort called “What Goes Around Comes Around”.

 What Goes Around Comes Around is a project that will start and end with the children of the pediatric cancer ward of the CHU-L’Archet-2 hospital in Nice, France. With the help of Dr. Soler, Pascale Cozzi and the Blouses Roses of CHU-L'Archet-2 Nice, the patients of CHU-L'Archet-2 will select a new name for their ward. Patients  of CHU-L'Archet-2 and the Lenval will then decorate a part of each letter. 

 The Blouses Roses are a wonderful group of volunteers that provide creative support for hospitalized children and the elderly. The Blouses Roses of CHU-L'Archet-2 Nice; Dominique Resegotti, Bernadette Negre and Marse Garcin along with Monique Barthelemy and her team at CHU-Lenval Nice embraced the project with exceptional enthusiasm, thus providing great support for the children of these hospitals enabling them to get the project off to a great start.

The letters will be sent to Ms. Ana Maria Cruz’s elementary school art students, at the American International School of Budapest in Hungary, who will learn how art can be used in service learning projects and add their own original ideas to the second third of each letterform. 

From there the letterforms will travel once again, this time to Paris, France where my daughter and her friends will add their creative ideas to the last third of each letterform. 

The final letterforms will travel once again, this time back to Nice to be the center piece of an art installation at the ECIS – European Council of International Schools – Conference at the Acropolis Conference Hall in Nice. During the first 3 days of this conference, visitors will have the opportunity of participating in the making of the mosaic mural by gluing glass tiles onto the final collaborative letterform designs. The final mosaic mural will be completed by members of the ECIS Art Committee and presented to the CHU-L'Archet-2 on Saturday November 24, 2012.Thus completing the cycle of“What Goes Around Comes Around”.

The Impact 

In a world filled with medicine, machines, and technology, it is amazing to see how the simple act of creating art together can make people smile. 

My Story

My name is Stacey Wilson "Jaco" McMahon. I am an African American artist and art teacher living and working in Paris France.

A graduate of Parsons School of Design Paris, France. My experiences in the art world include many art forms ranging from graphic design to calligraphy, silk painting, and mosaic work. I began teaching art 25 years ago.

It is my belief that each person is born with an innate desire and ability to create art in some form and that a persons life is a quest to find these hidden talents and create art that expresses their experiences, their spirit, and life around them thus becoming an artist.

I come from a family of patchwork quilt makers - the Jaco’s, from Salisbury, Missouri, USA.  My journey to creating and facilitating collaborative art projects began in 1990, on a visit back home to Salisbury, when my great Aunt Edna gave me some of our family heirloom quilts along with a pile of patchwork squares. They were over 100 years old.  Aunt Edna challenged me to carry on the Jaco tradition by encouraging me to incorporate the pieces into a new quilt. Since receiving those timeless treasures, it has been my quest to find a way to incorporate the concept of a patchwork – the art of joining together different pieces of art into one unified piece, that provides protection,  not only into my art and teaching but also into my way of life.

In 1995 my mother, who was an amazing artist, art teacher and my mentor, died of breast cancer. She had a long battle with the disease and went through the many changes that are typical of cancer patients: mis-diagnosis, doctor changes, clinical trials, chemotherapy, radiation and all the dreadful effects that accompany these treatments. In our many trips to the hospital, I noticed that patients spent long periods sitting around with their loved ones, awaiting their various treatments. The periods that cancer patients spend in the hospital, whether short or long, are critical, distressing times. Since my mother’s death I thought about using my art skills to improve the time people spend at the hospital. But at the time, I was as yet unclear how I could do this.

While living and teaching art on the island of Antigua, in the Caribbean, between 2000 - 2007, I took many of my lessons out of the classroom to construct and create art installations in the community such as murals, totem poles, grafitti’d crosses. I discovered how devoted my secondary students became when they were involved in creating art that had a specific purpose and a long-term benefit. I also learned how the collaborative process of designing and creating art installations brought people of different ages, races, religions and social backgrounds together for a common goal. Since 2000, I have created, facilitated and directed over 25 collaborative art projects in Antigua, France and the USA.

In 2010 I lost my second parent to cancer and decided it was time to make a difference and improve the quality of life for cancer patients, particularly those in hospitals. I wanted to focus on children not only because of my love for working with young people but also because I believe that throughout the ordeal of cancer treatments there should be something positive from their time spent in hospital and that they deserve to smile.

Since 2000, I have been facilitating collaborative art projects and installations that range from work with teenage girls on the island of Antigua in the Caribbean to work with young people of the Summer Youth Program of the Madison Park Development Corporation in Boston,Massachusetts  to work with children with cancer in France.

What We Need & What You Get

The funds raised for this project will cover all art supplies needed; paper, markers, colored pencils, glass mosaic tiles, tile grout, wood, mosaic glue, all mosaic tools as well as my travel expenses for 5 trips from Paris to Nice to organize the project, set up & operating costs, and an "unveiling" party at the CHU-L'Archet-2 Hospital in Nice for the children, their families, care givers, doctors, nurses and hospital staff. Any additional money raised will go towards funding new art projects with for children with cancer in hospitals in France. 

This project is an example of the collaborative art projects that my future non-profit organization apatchworks will provide. For more information please email me at apatchworks@gmail.com

Perks...

T-shirt Perk - The first 5 people who contribute $25 to the project will get a t-shirt with the final collaborative design.

Memory Book Perk - The first 5 people who contribute $100 will get a photo album with images of the project from beginning to end. 

Part of the Art Perk - Be a part of the collaborative art piece. The first 5 people who contribute $500 will get the first name of thier choice gold leafed into the final mosaic mural that will hang permenantly in the CHU-L'Archet-2 Hospital in Nice, France.

What happens if I don't reach my financial goal.

All funds raised will go towards the project.

Other Ways You Can Help...

If you can't make a financial contribution that is cool, just spread the word & use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Public Art for the Broadway Bridge in Portland, OR:

Greetings to bridge, public art and yarn lovers!  Bridge For Blankets is a community-based knit project, and temporary public art installation, set for install on the Broadway Bridge in August, 2013, as a part of the PDX Bridge Festival.  2013 is the Centennial Anniversary for the Broadway Bridge, and Bridge For Blankets is our way of drawing focus to this historical structure’s role in the Portland community.

This public art installation consists of 4 -18’ x 21’ knit banners hung outside the drawspans, on both the North and South sides of the Broadway Bridge.  The construction of these banners depends upon the support of 150+ knitting volunteers, local mainly to the Portland area.  After the project has been taken back down, these knit banners will be broken down into 42 - 6’ x 6’ afghans, washed, and donated to Portland area homeless shelters (i.e. Human Solutions & SnoCap).

Who is Helping Us?

Multnomah County is lending us their skilled engineers, those that manage and care for the Broadway Bridge, to help Bridge For Blankets go up on the Broadway for the month of August.  We are very grateful for their enthusiastic support of this multi-purpose art installation, and can’t wait to see the banners brightening up this iconic, brick-red bridge.  We need help raising the funds for installation materials and equipment rental, and that is one of the reasons that we are campaigning for your support on Indiegogo.

The knit banners will all be constructed from a colorful array of Cascade 220 Superwash Wool – a wool that will not felt, allowing the homeless shelter recipients to wash these blankets just as they would any other blanket.  Abundant Yarns (http://www.abundant-yarn.com) and Cascade Yarns (http://www.cascadeyarns.com/) have teamed together to offer us a significant discount on the wool we need to for the project, and for that, we are delighted beyond belief.  However, just as with the installation costs, we need your assistance to pay for the large yarn order.  It costs more to create an afghan from quality natural fibers, but we also know that using natural fibers makes the resulting charitable gesture mean more to the recipients.  Please help us pay for the yarn today by making a tax-deductible donation to Bridge For Blankets.

***** We have all the knitting volunteers that we require for this project.

 

How You Can Help:

We invite you to show your support and enthusiasm for what we are doing for the Portland community, and donate generously to Bridge For Blankets on this page.

When you make a donation of $130+ to our project today, you have paid for the yarn for one entire knit blanket.  We accept all donation levels; no donation amount is too great or too small.

Spread the word about this project by sharing the link to this crowdfunding page with your friends, family, neighbors, and co-workers.  Tweet, post on Facebook, and cast an even wider, and more personal, net by sharing our fundraising story via e-mail.  Want some 1/4 sheet cards to hand out to promote the project in hard copy form?  E-mail me at tyler.mackie@gmail.com.

We absolutely could not realize this project without your help.  Donate today, and help us bridge the gap, and restore lives for those within our homeless communities.

UPDATE: We will be installing the first panels on the bridge beginning July 20th, but we still need you donations to help us pay for the upfront cost of materials for installation, and the yarn being knit for donation.

Public Art for the Broadway Bridge in Portland, OR:
Greetings to bridge, public art and yarn lovers!  Bridge For Blankets is a community-based knit project, and temporary public art installation, set for install on the Broadway Bridge in August, 2013, as a part of the PDX Bridge Festival.  2013 is the Centennial Anniversary for the Broadway Bridge, and Bridge For Blankets is our way of drawing focus to this historical structure’s role in the Portland community.
This public art installation consists of 4 -18’ x 21’ knit banners hung outside the drawspans, on both the North and South sides of the Broadway Bridge.  The construction of these banners depends upon the support of 150+ knitting volunteers, local mainly to the Portland area.  After the project has been taken back down, these knit banners will be broken down into 42 - 6’ x 6’ afghans, washed, and donated to Portland area homeless shelters (i.e. Human Solutions & SnoCap).
Who is Helping Us?
Multnomah County is lending us their skilled engineers, those that manage and care for the Broadway Bridge, to help Bridge For Blankets go up on the Broadway for the month of August.  We are very grateful for their enthusiastic support of this multi-purpose art installation, and can’t wait to see the banners brightening up this iconic, brick-red bridge.  We need help raising the funds for installation materials and equipment rental, and that is one of the reasons that we are campaigning for your support on Indiegogo.
The knit banners will all be constructed from a colorful array of Cascade 220 Superwash Wool – a wool that will not felt, allowing the homeless shelter recipients to wash these blankets just as they would any other blanket.  Abundant Yarns (http://www.abundant-yarn.com) and Cascade Yarns (http://www.cascadeyarns.com/) have teamed together to offer us a significant discount on the wool we need to for the project, and for that, we are delighted beyond belief.  However, just as with the installation costs, we need your assistance to pay for the large yarn order.  It costs more to create an afghan from quality natural fibers, but we also know that using natural fibers makes the resulting charitable gesture mean more to the recipients.  Please help us pay for the yarn today by making a tax-deductible donation to Bridge For Blankets.
***** We have all the knitting volunteers that we require for this project.
 
How You Can Help:
We invite you to show your support and enthusiasm for what we are doing for the Portland community, and donate generously to Bridge For Blankets on this page.
When you make a donation of $130+ to our project today, you have paid for the yarn for one entire knit blanket.  We accept all donation levels; no donation amount is too great or too small.
Spread the word about this project by sharing the link to this crowdfunding page with your friends, family, neighbors, and co-workers.  Tweet, post on Facebook, and cast an even wider, and more personal, net by sharing our fundraising story via e-mail.  Want some 1/4 sheet cards to hand out to promote the project in hard copy form?  E-mail me at tyler.mackie@gmail.com.
We absolutely could not realize this project without your help.  Donate today, and help us bridge the gap, and restore lives for those within our homeless communities.
UPDATE: We will be installing the first panels on the bridge beginning July 20th, but we still need you donations to help us pay for the upfront cost of materials for installation, and the yarn being knit for donation.

story:
flow[er]

(www.vidhiandjen.tumblr.com)
(https://www.facebook.com/pages/Flow-er/494864770591413) 

We made this little blosoming baby over the course of a semester at university.After copious amounts of prototyping and pointless cutting up of foam, we have created flow[er] an interactive kinetic flower that responds to you!

As a user comes closer to the flower, it slowly “blossoms” and lights up and creates sound. The movement that the structure follows is also very calculated, reflective of urban spaces. 

The object is made up completely of recycled items, collected over time and found in second hand recycle stores, as a commentary on wastefulness today. The flower is made up entirely of old circuit boards collected form reverse garbage, a recycled items store. We use old jumper cables to attach the petals to a rotational servo, which connects these layers.

How it works

The servo is connected to a motion sensor. The signals from the sensor tell the flower to open up when it detects movement. When the flower opens up, the LEDs inside the flower also light up and turn off when the flower goes back to its closed state. We have used an Arduino board to write up all of the coding.

Who are we?

We are Jeniffer Heng and Vidhi Shah, two young naive girls who met on the campus of Queensland University of Technology.

Jeniffer Heng is in her final year of Interactive and Visual Design and Marketing. She constantly carries her little sketch book around and doodles her way through life.

Vidhi Shah is also in her final year of Interactive and Visual Design and Animation. She watches way too much tv that it possibly can't be good for her eyes.

With both of their powers combined they have created this kinetic sculpture that has been chosen to be exhibited at...

*drumroll*

THE ARS ELECTRONICA FESTIVAL (LINZ, AUSTRIA)

What is the Ars Electronica Festival?

The Ars Electronica fesitval is the largest digital art festival in the world. The festival is for arts, technology and society. The festival is often described as the Hollywood of computer art. Look how pretty their building is.

What We Need & What You Get

Making multiples of these flowers for display will cost us a lot of money and with your help we can make them come to life. 

We require 15 flow[er]s for displaying (including back ups). 

We would love for you folk to support us in our mission to take these flowers to Austria. In return of your support and love we have a whole lot of benifits to offer which you can see in the 'Perks' column. Any and all donations are welcome and appreciated. 

If we don't reach our entire goal, don't fret! Your money will not be wasted. Any money that is contributed will go in the production of these flowers and creating your perks. We might have to live on MiGoreng for a week or two or three, but we are determined to make this happen. 

No Cash? No worries! 

We understand if you can't sponsor us, we do ask you however to spread the word to your friends and family. Share this project on Facebook and Twitter and perhaps every other social media network possible. 

If nothing else, use the powers that you have learned after reading Rhonda Byrne's, The Secret, and with the sheer power of will, we will become the flow[er].

NOTE: payments are being made in USD and not AUD. Sorry about the inconvenience.

story:
For additional videos and press, please go to http://swipemagazine.com/press.php

___________________________________________________________________________________________________


WHO WE ARE 

SW!PE Magazine was founded in 2009, by artists working as guards at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It features the diverse creative output of fellow MET guards who are artists and writers, with work ranging from painting and performance to short stories and critical essays. The magazine is produced and published independently of the museum, which figures simply as the place where this particular group became acquainted.


WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Currently, the 127 page SW!PE Volume 2 is being prepared for printing, highlighting work that takes as it's subject the MET Museum.  As an independent magazine without advertising, we are turning to the public for financial support.  Currently the editors are providing funds for printing, and end up breaking even after the magazine is sold.  Any profits are put back into the magazine for further printing, but this doesn’t get us very far after reimbursing ourselves.  As guards our salaries are not impressive, so besides time and effort, we cannot invest the funds we require for future success.  


THE FUTURE 

Without outside funding, it won't be possible to realize the potential of what SW!PE Magazine could be.  The editors envision SW!PE becoming a global phenomenon, a magazine that shares the work of museum guards from around the world in effect creating a vast network of emerging talent.  In order to do this, we need to increase distribution, which means printing more magazines, which means raising more funds.

Please help us realize this vision with your support, and also, please check out the many perks we offer in appreciation of this support.


Thanks!

story:
The Bomb Shelter Museum: A Museum of Living History and Art Exhibit

More information here:

8,500 rockets have been fired at Israel since 2005 when Israel withdrew from Gaza. That's an average of 3 per day since 2001. Israel has every right to protect herself from the daily threat of these rockets. We need to expose this truth to the public eye. Help us bring this message to America's largest art festival, Art Basel.

Bomb Shelter Museum is a multi-media exhibit that simulates in exact detail the terrifying experience of living through a rocket attack in Israel's south. 

At Art Basel: Miami, 2012, A4I seeks to exhibit the Bomb Shelter Museum for a week in a central location directly in between two large art fairs. Equipped with the Tzeva Adom (Red Alert) alarm, we will send this alarm each and every time a rocket lands in Israel. There are 65,000 people who attend Basel.

Visitors to the exhibit often leave shocked and crying, vowing their support for Israel. The press always reports it - providing worldwide coverage about Israel's right to defend itself.

Look how effective: http://newyork.cbslocal.com/video/7144510-hsu-pkg-bomb-shelter-museum/

We hope that one day the Bomb Shelter Museum will be just that - a Museum because the actual shelters will be gone, unnecessary in a peaceful world.

story:
MUSETOUCH is a free magazine about visual arts. It has been created by Maia Sylba out of love and passion for art with the hope that people will be able to use the publication and website as a platform to showcase their skills and gain recognition.

"There is a story behind every creation...there is a story behind Musetouch too. I created it to escape from sorrow, great sadness I was going through. It helped me to find myself, to save myself and above all, to meet the most emaotinal, sensitive, imaginative kind of people...the artists. I heard their stories, I meet them...most of them became my close friends, and helping them became my aim, my greates wish, the purpose of my life.
I am working for free for two years now, trying to present as much artists as I can. Trying to connect them with agents, collectionars, gallery owners...for free.

Musetouch is a free magazine, all the presentations are free,the magazine's blog posts, official facebook fan page posts, pinterest, twitter...I am doing everything for free.

Yet, although I am giving my best and working 10-12 hours per day, I can't manage to finish everything that I plan and need to, which is making me quite sad and devastated. There are tons  and tons of emails to which I didn't manage to answer, artists I didn't manage to present, people I couldn't help.

I need funds to finish the web site for Musetouch which will allow people to upload their creations by themselves, web site where they will be able to connect with agents, gallery owners, collectionars and byers. The web site where they will be able to make their own profiles, a little shops that will make possible for them to sell their works. My plan is not to take any provision from the selling. I am devastated with other web sites who are taking even 70% of every work sold, greedy people who are using artists and their  creativity, their hard work to gain abundance, to get rich. I never thought that was fair...I think that is even more than rude. That is so called modern capitalism.

There is no bigger crime but to use others people hard work and think about them as a number, not a living human being with feelings.

I plan to take only symbolic $5 per year from every artist as a membership fee just to cover hosting and server expenses of the web site that are already huge, but I am paying them by myself for  two years now and I don't know how long will I manage.

My work...everything that I do, which includes presentations and promotions of the artists, promotion of the web site, getting connections and advicing the artists, writing interviews and creating the magazine itself will remain free for ever. I just want to be able to dedicate myself completely to the magazine and people I present.

That is why we need your help.

Every donation will mean a fortune for us and we will know how to appreciate it, no matter how small it is...the most important is that it is coming from the heart.

Helping Musetouch and all the artists I presented and will be presenting in the future, is a beautiful cause, a noble cause, humane cause and I thank you with all my heart in my name and in the name of all of them."

Maia Sylba, creator and editor

 






"I am proud of you for your work in Musetouch and also inspired...it is also as if language cannot contain nor express the passion dreams and art of the artists...but there you are on your golden surfboard riding on the tumultous waves of muse....you too a muse...the question being what images to send you as my vision embraces the earth, the worlds, the many levels and dimensions of reality, fantasy, light and shadow, light and darkness...you know the work of Balthus and Lewis Carrol are part of that phrase Diane Arbus wrote regarding do not fear to photograph what draws your heart and soul...for it is the child wherein dwells the dream...and we who live briefly beyond that time we were child..remain within child ...and when there...we are not far from that time when we were before birth...coming from the great ocean of darkness and dreams to the ocean of light and awareness...it is said that "before we were, we were loved and named, and from the source
of creation the yearning that we might grow and appear in our utmost beauty"...so I am drawn to the memory and the presence of the child with the fantasy and dreams...but not an idealized concept alone because even as children we are more aware and feeling and passionate than adults are williing to remember...if anything their is both a fear of that time an attempt to both supress the boundliess energy and curiosity of childhood...to force the child to become filled with the rigid thinking gird of superstition and shame and repression...while in truth they are like hollow reeds from which
the most beautiful thoughts and music can flow...all having deserved that mothers love, that milk and nurturing and celebration...that time of oness with the god of life, beauty and creation...that ebb and flow of beauty from the ocean of our dreams and desires, of our life and death...from whence we all come and go...so there...within this world and reality we dwell in...there is aloso the invisible but present dimensions of dream and fantasy...the delicate tendrils of love that encircle us with sweet breath....from which we are called upon to see, guard, protect and nourish...so I am lost in words...lost in the beauty and mystery that pervades the impulse of your Musetouch....for truly with our art and vision and music and dance and form we touch, we kiss and are kissed, embrace and are embraced...we rise, child and old grandparents, lovers, we rise and transcend this eartlhly form...like sweet fragrent wisps of spoke...yes words fail us...but we stand ever the child
full of wonder by the night sea, neath the sky of endless stars...neath the pulsating throbbing rising undulating light"

Mark Sadan, fine art photographer and director of the legendary Sesame Street.

story:
Summary

I need your help to preserve a creative legacy and you can experience those works for yourself by participating.

Since 1980, I have been involved in the creation and production of hundreds of independent artistic works and events.  These have included music and sound art, live music performances, video productions and screenings, graphic design, photography and written works both fictional and analytical.  These have been produced both independently, as a solo artist, and in collaboration within various groups and creative collectives.  My role in these has ranged from performer to producer to marketing and distribution management, all the way down to the nuts and bolts of administration.  

Throughout all of the years I've been producing, one of my primary concerns has been the preservation of these works in some form.  For the past dozen or so years, this has been focused on digitally capturing and storing this material in whatever medium has been available from compact discs to hard drives.  For the most part, these means of data storage have proven tenuous, at best.  Discs become corrupted within a couple of years, hard drives fail generally in less than five years.  Cloud storage is still prohibitively expensive and lacking in security.

At the time of this writing, the entirety of the creative output I have been involved with resides on a single hard drive that is disturbingly showing signs of wear.  While some small portion of this material does have off site storage, a large amount of it is only on this one drive and teetering on the brink of destruction should anything befall this fragile vessel.  

The purpose of this campaign is to, at minimum, invest in at least one backup hard drive of sufficient capacity, quality and reliability to ensure that this precious data may be preserved for another few years - long enough to make it to the next point of preservation with whatever new technology may appear by then.  

These are not famous works.  They are known by few and loved by fewer, but they ARE loved and they DO have the potential to one day reach a larger audience should they manage to survive into an uncertain future.  By supporting this campaign, you can participate in that preservation process and become part of the story by sharing in this content and discovering it for yourself.

At the present time, my means are strained.  As an independent artist, I have no source of support for these works beyond what I can muster.  Employment opportunities have been few and unreliable.  Recorded music now offers virtually no opportunities for sales for producers who appeal to small audiences.  This is the only means by which I can preserve these works.  Your support is critical to the future survival of a lifetime's work.  But, best of all, you get to experience it by helping it survive.

What I Need & What You Get

In order to ensure the safety and preservation of the creative legacy I've invested over 30 years of my life producing, I need to purchase at least one high quality (excellent longevity & reliability stats), high capacity (3-4 TB) backup hard drive.   What you will receive in return for your support will be as follows:

At the $22.00 level...

  • Download of a two volume "best of" collection specially selected for this project containing 22 original audio works.  
  • Copious bonus graphics files, digital photos & texts.
  • A selection of original music videos.
At the $4.00 level, you'll receive a download of a selected audio album from the archive.

Other Ways You Can Help

I'm only one person.   I can spread the word on this campaign only so far.  You can help and that help could be exponential if it takes off.  Spread the word.  Share this on your social media.  Let people know about it.  Tell them about the work.  

You can also directly support these works by purchasing high quality downloads from the Bandcamp site linked to my IndieGogo profile.  There are hundreds of titles in various different styles to select from.  If you want some recommendations, just message me and let me know what you generally like.

Time is running out on these works unless you get involved.  Help keep the art alive and you'll get to enjoy it yourself by doing so.

Don't forget to check out the gallery section of this campaign for video and image samples from the archive.  If you like what you see and hear, contribute!

The purpose of this campaign is to, at minimum, invest in at least one backup hard drive of sufficient capacity, quality and reliability to ensure that this precious data may be preserved for another few years - long enough to make it to the next point of preservation with whatever new technology may appear by then.  
These are not famous works.  They are known by few and loved by fewer, but they ARE loved and they DO have the potential to one day reach a larger audience should they manage to survive into an uncertain future.  By supporting this campaign, you can participate in that preservation process and become part of the story by sharing in this content and discovering it for yourself.
At the present time, my means are strained.  As an independent artist, I have no source of support for these works beyond what I can muster.  Employment opportunities have been few and unreliable.  Recorded music now offers virtually no opportunities for sales for producers who appeal to small audiences.  This is the only means by which I can preserve these works.  Your support is critical to the future survival of a lifetime's work.  But, best of all, you get to experience it by helping it survive.   What I Need & What You Get In order to ensure the safety and preservation of the creative legacy I've invested over 30 years of my life producing, I need to purchase at least one high quality (excellent longevity & reliability stats), high capacity (3-4 TB) backup hard drive.   What you will receive in return for your support will be as follows:
At the $22.00 level...


Download of a two volume "best of" collection specially selected for this project containing 22 original audio works.  
Copious bonus graphics files, digital photos & texts.
A selection of original music videos.

At the $4.00 level, you'll receive a download of a selected audio album from the archive.


Other Ways You Can Help

I'm only one person.   I can spread the word on this campaign only so far.  You can help and that help could be exponential if it takes off.  Spread the word.  Share this on your social media.  Let people know about it.  Tell them about the work.  
You can also directly support these works by purchasing high quality downloads from the Bandcamp site linked to my IndieGogo profile.  There are hundreds of titles in various different styles to select from.  If you want some recommendations, just message me and let me know what you generally like.
Time is running out on these works unless you get involved.  Help keep the art alive and you'll get to enjoy it yourself by doing so.
Don't forget to check out the gallery section of this campaign for video and image samples from the archive.  If you like what you see and hear, contribute!

story:
2014 has been a year full of changes for me, and instead of letting that energy go to waste, I've decided to channel it into art--in particular, jewelry. My previous jewelry endeavors include the Campbell Award tiara and the lampwork bracelet "Shoggoths In Bloom," which inspired Elizabeth Bear's Hugo Award-winning short of the same name.

I enjoy making wire-link or sculptural wire pieces with sterling or gold-fill wire. Some of my favorite materials are semi-precious stones, pearls, lampwork, glass, and bone. The most interesting pieces of jewelry have stories in them, and I try to coax those out whenever I can.

All contributions to Still So Strange Studios go toward materials. Jewelry production begins as soon as I have the component parts. If you choose one of the available perk options, your requests will be the first pieces made (in order of contributions received). All funds beyond those needed for contributor custom orders will go to shinies sold through my Etsy shop, which will be up by year's end.

ETA: If you sign up for one of the jewelry options, please comment here or send me an email (exoblivione at gmail) letting me know your color/material preferences. I'll order the first round of supplies soon.

story:
Hello Folks!

It's Rainbow here, the sole creative force behind Rainboeliza Studios.  A graduate from the Pacific Northwest College of art and active artist, I'm looking to build a studio to accomplish several goals that includes continuing to grow my practice, teaching a love and appreciation for the arts, fundraising for folks in need, responsibly paying off my student loan debt, and continuing to put on annual projects that help raise an interest and show the importance of the arts [ Check out some of these projects here & here & here!].  

First a little more about me: I went back to college a few years ago to conquer one of my three ever persistent dreams: To become an artist [or rather to get the full training and wisdom of the educational art experience].  I knew it was going to be a difficult and expensive venture and indeed it was.  However, a love for printmaking emerged [check out one of my many projects here!]!  Now, even though I'm gainfully employed [though, sadly, far from what I'd love to be doing and went to school for], funds are exceptionally tight as I strive to pay off the ole' student loan debt.  My studio is in a corner of a small room forty minutes from where I live and is far from ideal for working or teaching.  I've been saving funds to build a studio [I'm up to $550.], but the savings is growing at a very slow rate - very slow.  In fear of losing my artistic mojo by the educational debt that consumes me, I am on a mission to make it happen sooner rather then later while far from adversed to working hard to do so! Hence, I've got to get this studio built and I've made some perks I feel are worth it in order "to make it happen"!

• Now, I would love for it to be on wheels and easily movable [Ah, a portable studio! Check out the small portable studios I've made here & here!], but a trailer is a huge expense [~$1000.] and is pending due to funds.  Yet, wouldn't it be wonderful to travel the USA [maybe other countries connecting too] to share, learn and create, or design an art residency of some sort . . . Oh the dreams that spring from one. . . 

Down to Business 

Looking to build an 8'x12' studio with my own blood sweat and tears [+ a friend too] to cut labor costs.  The studio, thanks to the nature of the print medium, will need to be well insulated, heated in winter/cooled in summer, and have an electric hookup.  Although my goal is to use reclaimed materials when possible for environmental/cost effective purposes, I've estimated costs below based on new materials from big box stores to be on the safe side: 

  • Windows/Door: ~ $375.oo
  • Wood/Roofing: ~ $500.oo
  • Hardware [nails, screws, hinges, etc.]: ~ $50.oo
  • Drywall/Sheet Rock/Insulation: ~ $225.oo
  • Misc. [heater, paint, other, indiegogo fees, etc.]: ~ $200.oo

TOTAL: $1350.oo

Ah, you may notice  $550.oo + $600.oo is $200.oo short of the overall goal.  There are two reasons: 1. I am continuing to save funds and certain things will be added to the studio over time.  & 2. I know for a fact that some items I will be able to get for much less gently used.  It is not my goal to be over zealous and have a pimped out studio, but rather to have a sturdy, functional one, where I can continue my practice via mentioned above.  Would it be wonderful if I sucessfuly raised far above my goal?  Most certainly!  In the event that I did, I would add new tools to the studio such as a paper cutter, a larger press and so forth.  However, on the sad side of raising significantly less?  I simply will continue to plug away until enough funds are saved. . .

Oh, and wondering just how I'm going to build the studio?  With help from my fine gentlemen friend who has built several similar small structures before!  Plus, if you take a look at my blog and click on "Lust a Small Space" in the cloud of words to the left, you'll find I've been reading and taking in quite a bit about building small structures over the last few years.  We can do it!

Why Help?

Yes, there are a ton of artist out there, but by helping now you could:

  • Learn how to print! Make a book! Or?? 
  • Pick up a gift!
  • Pick up some art!
  • Support the arts!
  • Help keep the the written postcard alive [phew, technology sure is taking over this!]
  • Spread positive karma/juju
  • Make a connection with me! [We all have something to offer one another!  Making connections is how I was able to travel to France, India, & South Korea! It's how I find out about unique opportunities, how I learn and how I grow - Let's reap the benefits of shared knowledge! check out my blog to see and read more: rainboeliza.blogspot.com 

Other Ways You Can Help

Have no funds at the moment or the perks don't meet your fancy, but you'd like to help?

  • Spread the word via social media & use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • There might be something at the ole' Etsy Shop! https://www.etsy.com/shop/rainboeliza
  • Join the Rainboeliza Facebook Page and keep afloat for other projects
  • Have some goods to donate? A sturdy door, windows, supplies etc.? Have some excellent on the cheap ideas or places to purchase from? Or have a better idea for a perk? Just drop a line and let us know!

 

And that’s all there is to it.

Learn how to print! Make a book! Or?? 

Pick up a gift!

Pick up some art!
Support the arts!
Help keep the the written postcard alive [phew, technology sure is taking over this!]

Spread positive karma/juju

Make a connection with me! [We all have something to offer one another!  Making connections is how I was able to travel to France, India, & South Korea! It's how I find out about unique opportunities, how I learn and how I grow - Let's reap the benefits of shared knowledge! check out my blog to see and read more: rainboeliza.blogspot.com 





Other Ways You Can Help
Have no funds at the moment or the perks don't meet your fancy, but you'd like to help?


Spread the word via social media & use the Indiegogo share tools!

There might be something at the ole' Etsy Shop! https://www.etsy.com/shop/rainboeliza

Join the Rainboeliza Facebook Page and keep afloat for other projects
Have some goods to donate? A sturdy door, windows, supplies etc.? Have some excellent on the cheap ideas or places to purchase from? Or have a better idea for a perk? Just drop a line and let us know!


 
And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Thank you so much to everyone who has already backed our little campaign.  Due to your generosity I am happy to report that the 2014 Calendar will happen!  But we aren't done, in fact we are just getting started. 

With your continued support we can make even more Geeky Goodness happen.  With that we move on to our stretch goals.  
 

Here is our T-Shirt Designs!  Details on purchasing a T-Shirt will be added soon. 

$15,000: Get GeekGoddess to YOUR Favorite Convention.  Suggest a convention, any convention in the USA, and we will hold a popular vote.  We will then attend the winning convention, as long as that convention will have us.  Outside the US?  Sorry but due to the costs of taking Goddesses abroad this won't be feasible....  just yet ;).  

Goals Reached: 

$3,000: The 2014 GeekGoddess Calendar is HAPPENING!

$3,500: We are getting GeekGoddess T-Shirts made.  The funds raised will help us get the artwork and set up the screen printing.    Stay tuned for more information.  If you donated money we will be providing information on how to purchase a discounted shirt.  

$5,000: We will make Posters featuring all of the current Geek Goddesses together in one image.  Anyone who donated $25 or more will receive one for free.




Anyone who gives anything will receive our gratitude, even if you can only chip in a dollar.  But after that you’ll start to see some special rewards based on your donation amount.  


$5:  We will personally thank you in the Calendar. 


$10:  Receive a 4x6 mini-print featuring the Goddess of your choice.  


$25: You can choose to either receive a copy of the finished calendar shipped to you or an exclusive 8x10 photo print of the Goddess of your choice.  Non-US based contributers please select the international perk or include an additional $10 for shipping. 


$50:  Receive both a copy of the calendar and your choice of exclusive print.  Non-US based contributers please select the international perk or include an additional $10 for shipping. 


$100: Receive a copy of the calendar along with your choice of 4 exclusive prints.


$200: Receive a copy of the calendar along with a complete set of the exclusive prints.

*Shipping* Shipping is included in all perks for shipment within the USA.  For International Shipping please include an extra $10 at the $10,$25 and $50 level or select the international version of the Perk. THANKS!

*Delivery* Our plan is to have the calendar completed and ready for public consumption over Labor Day Weekend (August 30th-September 2nd). As we'll be out of town at event over these days you prints/calendars should ship out after we get home in early September.  If we finish early we'll send copies out as soon as possible. 



Other Ways You Can Help

Are you strapped for cash and unable to help us directly?  You can still help us get out the word using the Indiegogo share tools! 
 

Referall Contest:  

There is a new way to help GeekGoddess reach our next stretch goal.   Refer your friends to our campaign to help us reach our goal and maybe you can get a little something in return.   We have options for both individuals and companies.  

The first step:  Regardless of whether you are a company or an individual you will need to create an account on Indiegogo to participage.   Otherwise we will not be able to see the traffic you drive and give you credit for your contribution.  Once you have an account you can use Indiegogo's share tools.  

Share Tools are located at the top of the page directly below the video. 

What you might get? 

Individuals:  The person who sends the most referral traffic/donations our way will receive a free GeekGoddess T-Shirt.  

Companies:  The company who sends us the most referral traffic/donations will receive a free ad in our Calendar along with a banner on our website.

*Important*:  If you are a company and it isn't obvious from your referral name you must send us a message and let us know.  Otherwise we may treat you as an individual.   

Greetings fellow Geeks and Nerds.  Perhaps you're already a fan of GeekGoddess, maybe you are just hearing about us for the first time.  If you are let me take a quick moment to explain who we are.  We are a site run by two incredibly Geeky women that features pinups of equally geeky and/or nerdy ladies, our Goddesses.

You get to help us fund a truly EPIC GeekGoddess Calendar.  

Our Goddesses already have some amazing ideas and costumes in the works to make this Calendar truly spectacular.  As we go we’ll be updating with images from those shoots.  For now we can only give you a taste of the kinds of things you’ll be able to expect.  

More than simply images of our Goddesses in costume the Calendar shots will be truly EPIC, combining our lovely Goddesses with some iconic costumes and amazing scenes that just aren’t feasible when we are shooting an entire set of 60+ images for our site.  


By our conservative estimates the whole project will cost us at least $3,000.  

This includes the cost of paying models, photographers and getting the calendars printed.  Of course, if our supporters are generous we can add and do even more amazing things.  Every penny we receive will go right back into making GeekGoddess even better and giving our fans even more geeky goodness.  

In addition to the Calendar, we will also be saving some extra images from each Goddesses calendar shoot.  From these images we will be selecting one of each Goddess that will be an exclusive print available only through this fundraiser.  You won’t be able to buy it later.

story:
Art on my Mind: The Poet


Shyla is a  body of flesh, transformed into a poem-on-napkin, trying her best to clean up the mess she's made of.


The first time I realized I was a poet I realized I wasn’t breathing correctly. I began to inhale through my nose and exhale through my lips; poems followed. For me poetry is an act of resistance by means of self-expression, self-recognition and self-love. Poetry is breathing. There is no way to succinctly introduce what poetry is for me without acknowledging that poetry is a part of who I am but mostly what I am striving to become.


Shyla is also a member of the 2013 Art Amok Slam team, winner of both Individual World Poetry Slam qualifiers in Atlanta, and probably wants to be your friend. 


Where we stand: What I Need & What You Get

To get to nationals I need

Plane ticket 

Hotel

Food

What you get for donating

Poems

Virtual Hugs

& any other Perks listed on the right column of the webpage -->


Teaching Community: 

The Significance of My Attendance at IWPS


While at Nationals, I will have the opportunity to attend workshops and network with poets from all over the nation.  I will bring these lessons and connections back home to enrich the literary lives of the Atlanta community.  


All About Love: Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help out by:

  •  making some noise about this campaign.
  • sharing and liking this campaign on your social networks.

story:
Help us launch, get Weird Gear and fly your freak flag--and help Bullied Kids.

Do you (or someone you love) have "the gift of not fitting in"?

I'm author, speaker and weird-guy, Jacob Nordby. I grew up feeling quite out of place in the normal world. I tried so hard, but the special talents and perspective I always had never quite fit in.

Later in life, I discovered many others who share this experience.

So, I wrote these words for all of us:

Blessed are the weird people - poets, misfits, writers, mystics, heretics, painters & troubadours -  for they teach us to see the world through different eyes.

Help us launch BlessedAreTheWeird.com and receive Weird Gear in return!

We are raising cash to build a web store and set up inventory of Weird Gear which will include:

  • Posters
  • T-Shirts
  • Mugs
  • Bumper Stickers
  • Other groovy stuff

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $3,500 which will be used to build a great website and online store--and purchase the Weird Gear necessary to kick this thing off.

This is a win-win deal because we've set the contribution levels at about what you'd pay for these items when we start offering them for sale. So, help us out and you get stuff you want anyway!

In return for your contributions, we'll send you "thank you swag". Here's how that works:

 

Donate $10 =
Get a "Blessed Are The Weird" poster!

19x27 high-quality poster, perfect to hang anywhere people need a reminder of just how cool you really are

Original Art by Barb Black. 

Donate $15 =

  •  The "Champagne Mug"

mug will be imprinted with a stylized Weird Eye and slogan.

 

 

 

Donate $25 =

  • Get a "Blessed Are The Weird" poster

  • PLUS a Champagne Mug

 

 

Donate $50 =

  • Get a "Blessed Are The Weird" poster

  • PLUS Champagne Mug

  • PLUS T-Shirt

 Donate $100 =

  • Get a "Blessed Are The Weird" poster

  • PLUS Champagne Mug

  • PLUS T-shirt

  • PLUS autographed copy of Jacob Nordby's "The Divine Arsonist" book

More information about this book can be found here: http://yourawakenedself.com/books/

 

Grand Exalted Patron of the Arts

Donate $500 =

  • All of the above 

  • PLUS a Barb Black original custom painting!

 

 

 

 

The Impact - Help Us Make A Difference For Bullied Kids

After BlessedAreTheWeird.com is launched, it will benefit the world in a couple of important ways:

  1. A portion of all proceeds from sales on the site will be given to support the work of people who help Bullied Kids in schools.
  2. This site will celebrate the work of artists, writers, musicians and other weird-cool people on its blog. We'll host special contests to drive major attention to the work of indies who might otherwise struggle to be heard above the noise.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate, that's okay! We would be very grateful if you'll let your friends on Facebook, Twitter and other places like that know about what we're doing.
story_txt:
Help us launch, get Weird Gear and fly your freak flag--and help Bullied Kids.
Do you (or someone you love) have "the gift of not fitting in"?
I'm author, speaker and weird-guy, Jacob Nordby. I grew up feeling quite out of place in the normal world. I tried so hard, but the special talents and perspective I always had never quite fit in.
Later in life, I discovered many others who share this experience.
So, I wrote these words for all of us:
Blessed are the weird people - poets, misfits, writers, mystics, heretics, painters & troubadours -  for they teach us to see the world through different eyes.
Help us launch BlessedAreTheWeird.com and receive Weird Gear in return!
We are raising cash to build a web store and set up inventory of Weird Gear which will include:

Posters
T-Shirts
Mugs
Bumper Stickers
Other groovy stuff



What We Need & What You Get
We are raising $3,500 which will be used to build a great website and online store--and purchase the Weird Gear necessary to kick this thing off.
This is a win-win deal because we've set the contribution levels at about what you'd pay for these items when we start offering them for sale. So, help us out and you get stuff you want anyway!
In return for your contributions, we'll send you "thank you swag". Here's how that works:

 
Donate $10 =Get a "Blessed Are The Weird" poster!
19x27 high-quality poster, perfect to hang anywhere people need a reminder of just how cool you really are


Original Art by Barb Black. 
Donate $15 =



 The "Champagne Mug"


mug will be imprinted with a stylized Weird Eye and slogan.
 
 
 
Donate $25 =


Get a "Blessed Are The Weird" poster


PLUS a Champagne Mug


 
 
Donate $50 =


Get a "Blessed Are The Weird" poster


PLUS Champagne Mug



PLUS T-Shirt




 Donate $100 =


Get a "Blessed Are The Weird" poster


PLUS Champagne Mug


PLUS T-shirt


PLUS autographed copy of Jacob Nordby's "The Divine Arsonist" book


More information about this book can be found here: http://yourawakenedself.com/books/

All of the above

story:
Who is Grandfather?

Grandfather is a big scale wooden sculpture.

He is seven meter tall, spreading his good vibes around, like your good old grandpa.

Grandpa is alive and likes to party!

At night,  he lights up with thousands of colorful LED lights.

Grandfather can feel you.

He  has movement sensors, so when you approach him, the colors change with the pace of his heart.

We are a group of six creators from different fields.

Each of us devotes his time, skills and efforts to make grandpa come alive.

This project will take place in the first Israeli burning man festival

EVER !

Midburn.

(Sweet environment for grandpa)

We invite you to take part in the magic.

Grndfather needs you

Here's an eye candy from the creators of this amazing project

 (That's granfather small child - the boy from south tel aviv)


The Burning Man experience

The Midburn event is the official regional event organized by the Midburn community – the Israeli Burning Man community. For 5 days, a temporary city will be set up in the Negev desert, creating a platform which will allow a communal life style, creativity, art and radical self-expression.


What We Need & What You Get

Grandfather project costs 2500$

It goes like this:

Wood and Screws: 520$

LED lights and electronics: 670$

Getting sabale down to the desert: 1285$

Indigogo fee: 175$

Beer: 25$

Whatever we  don't succeed to fundraise we will fund from our own pockets.

By contributing to this project you will get to be apart of this art exhibition in the first burning man festivel in Israel.

Your support will be forever honored and rememberd.

 We have some cool perks!

Grandfather's crew Thank you for your contribution

-------------------------------------------------------

story:
The 2015 MFA candidates at the University of Minnesota want to create a catalog for our thesis exhibition. Our goal is to raise $3500. The funds will be used to pay for a graphic designer to create a logo for the exhibition catalog and press materials, a writer who is contributing essays about the exhibiting artists, and to cover the costs of having the catalog printed. If we exceed our goal, excess funds will be used for miscellaneous expenses related to the thesis exhibition, including the production and installation of artwork.

All contributions of $25 or more will be rewarded with a copy of the catalog, as well as a piece of original artwork by one of the ten MFA candidates:

Beth Dow
Mara Duvra
Chris Groth
Jim Hittinger
Will Lakey
Joshua McGarvey
Candice Methe-Hess
Lorena Molina
Kevin Obsatz
Erin Paradis

Check out the perks and gallery page for images and descriptions of available pieces.

Please share this campaign and help us make our thesis exhibition the best it can be. Any contribution helps. Thank you!
